It is a wel gode time, a pli?t, To chirche goþ al to ni?t & pray to Crist so gode & fre, A king ous sende, þat bihouesum be To þe ri?t o?ains þe wrong, He graunt to chesen ous among, & þat we haue þer of tokening To morwe at our seruise ending!” & þat it so mi?t ben, Euerichon seyden: ‘amen!’ Þus þer ?ede more & lasse A ni?t to chirche, amorwe to masse, & maden solempne bisecheinge, For to haue a ri?tful kinge, & þo þe seruise don was, Outward þai wenten her pas; Tofor þe chirche dore þai founde A ston stonden on þe grounde, Long & hei?e, for soþe to say, Þer in a swerd of gret noblay. King & douke, baroun & kni?t, Ich hadde wonder of þat si?t; Þe bischop com & it sey?e & þonked Jesu Crist on hei?e. Ichil wele, þat ?e it wite, On þe pomel was ywrite: ‘Icham yhot Estalibore, Vnto a king fair tresore.’ On Inglis is þis writeing Kerue, stiel & iren al þing. Þe bischop seyd to hem anon: “Þis swerd who drawe of þe ston, He schal be our king ymade Bi godes wille & our rade!” Þai ?aue al her to concentement. King Lot proued, verrament, Out it to drawe anon ri?t, Ac he no mi?t for alle his mi?t; King Nanters no king Clarion No mi?t it drawe out of þe ston. No no gentil man of priis No mi?t it ones stiren, ywis. Þider com ich noble blod, & to candelmesse þer it stode; Al þat was born in Inglond, On þis swerd cast his hond, Ac, for liif no for deþe, Þai no mi?t it stir vnneþe. Þer it stode til ester tide; Þider to comen men ful wide Fram þis half se & eke bi?onde, & nou?t þai sped, bi godes sond. & ?ete it stode to pentecost, Þer com þider mani an ost, To turnaien in þat tide Al most fast þer bi side. Kay, his sone, sir Antour Him made kni?t wiþ gret honour; Þis Kay it was, þat nas nou?t late, For to souken his moder tate, Ac Arturet, for soþe, it seke, Þat bicom mild & meke. Kay was swiþe noble kni?t, Ac he stamered a litel wi?t, Þat, he it hadde in nortoure Þurch þe norices coure. Arthour had serued Lot Swiþe long, wele y wot. Ac þo Cay was kni?t ymade, Sir Antor ?af to Kay rade, For to ofsende Arthour o?ein, For to make of him his swain, For he was hardi, trewe & trest, Of al þis lond & ?ong man best. Kay was swiþe wele ypaid; Al was don, þat Antor seyd. Arthour com hom & was wiþ Kay, & went hem to þat turnay; Þer Kay contend him, a pli?t, So a wele doinde kni?t; Boþe at side & at ende He feld kni?tes swiþe hende. Þo he com amidward, About he leyd on so hard, Þat his swerd brast atvo, Anon he bad Arthour þo: “To mi leuedi swiþe wende, Anoþer swerd bid hir me sende!” & so he dede wiþ outen abode, Swiftliche hom he rode; His leuedi finde he no mi?t, O?ain he went anon ri?t. & to þe swerd in þe ston Wel ri?t he gan for to gon, Noman was þer, verrament, Ac alle weren at þe turnament. Arthour tok þe hilt bi hond, Þe swerd out drawe he gan fond, Ac for nou?t out it cam; In his hond he it nam, His hors he lepe vp anon, To þe turnay he com son & seyd: “Haue þis swerd, sir Kay! Þi leuedi finden y no may!” Kay þis swerd wele knewe, ywis, To Arthour he seyd: “Where hadestow þis?” “Certes,” quaþ Arthour, “her bi?onde In a ston ich it fond!” Arthour no sei?e it neuer ar No wist neuer, why it stode þar. Sir Kay seyd þo to Arthour: “Telle it to no man, par amour, Þat þou þis swerd out drou?, & þou schal haue gode ynou?!” Arthour seyd: “Certes, nay!” Forþ went anon sir Kay & ledde his fader, sir Antour, To þe chirche of seyn sauour & seyd: “Ichaue þis swerd out drawe: Þat ich be king, it is lawe!” Sir Antor biheld þat sword & seyd at þe first word: “Þou gabbest me, bi god aboue: ?if þou say soþ, eft þou it proue! For bifor þis hei?e men Þou most it pelt in o?en, & bot þou mi?test drawe it out, Þe wold schame berd & snout!” Þai wenten boþe to þe ston & Kay pelt it in anon, Ac þei he war strong & wi?t, Drawe it out he no mi?t. Þo bispac him sir Antour: “Telle me, sone, par amour, Who it was, þis swerd out drou??” & þo stode sir Kay & lou?: “Sir,” he seyd, “bi godes sond: Arthour toke it me in hond!” Antor cleped Arthour þo & dede him to þe ston go, & boþe swiþe & eke soft In & out he pelt it oft. Antor was her of ful bliþe & drou? Arthour to chirche swiþe & seyd to him priueliche þo: “Arthour, listen now me to! Seþþen þou were born, verrament, Ich haue ?ouen þe norisement.” & þer he teld him al þe cas, Hou he bi?eten & born was, Hou his fader was þe king, & hou, þurch his bisecheing, “Kay, mi sone, a norice y toke, & þou mi wiues tate soke.” Þo seyd Antor: “Min coure, Mi sone þou art þurch norture; It nis no ri?t, þat þou me werne, Ri?tfulliche þat y wil ?erne, Ich pray þe, graunt me a bone, Þat ich þe wil axi sone: Ich þe wil help, sone Arthour, King to ben wiþ michel honour!” Þo bispac Arthour, þe hende: “Crist of heuen me defende, Þat ich þe wern ani þing, Of what þou makest axing!” “God þe for?eld!” seyd sir Antour; “Now y þe pray par amour: Þi steward make mi sone Kay, So long so þou liue may! In nesse, in hard, y pray þe nowe, In al stedes þou him avowe, & y schal þe help in þis nede, Þurch godes help þat þou schalt spede!” Þo bispac him sir Arthour: “Y graunt þi wil, sir Antour, Þat Kay, þi sone, be mi steward; Y schal him avowe in nesse & hard! When ich euer faile Kay, Crist me for?ete þat day!” Forþ ?ede Antor anon ri?t & sir Arthour made kni?t; First he fond him cloþ & cradel, Þo he fond him stede & sadel, Helme & brini & hauberioun, Saumbers, quissers & aketoun, Quarre scheld, gode swerd of stiel & launce stef, biteand wel. Þer he ?aue him anon ri?tes To his seruise fourti kni?tes. A morwe þai went to turnament, & so þer dede, verrament, Þat ich day sir Arthour, Þe los he bar & þe honour. A morwe Antor, þat was nou?t nice, Went to þe bischop Brice & teld him, he wist a kni?t, Boþe gent & noble, a pli?t: “Þat schuld be our king wiþ lawe, For he may þat swerd out drawe!” Þe bischop was her of bliþe & sent after Arthour swiþe; Toforn al þe hei?e of þe lond Arthour tok þe swerd in hond; He drou? it out & pelt o?en: Wonder hadde mani men, For no man stiren it no mi?t, Bot he on, y ?ou pli?t. King & erls, wiþ outen dout, Þer gun him anon rebout, For to prouen his maner; Ac euer he was of milde chere, No couþe her non better deuise, Þan he hem answerd in al wise. Sir Antor him halp al so, Þat he was king chosen þo; & þer was boden to his gestening Mani prince & mani king; Al, þat euer com wold, At seyn Jon tide com schold. Merlin com hem bitven, Sir Arthour, þe prince, to sen, Of whos come miche blis Sir Arthour made, ywis. Swiþe anon hete Merlin, Men schuld ofsende þe douke Vlfin. Sir Jordains & sir Bretel, Þat hadde yben wiþ Tintagel. Al þre þai comen swiþe, Merlin was þer of wel bliþe; Merlin seyd: “Y wil, ?e wite, Hou þat Arthour was bi?ete!” Þer he told hem ende & ord, Of his bi?ete eueri word, Whar of Vlfin wittnes bar & seyd, certes, þat he was þar, & Antor bar witnesse þer to & seyd, þe king him seyd so. Þo loued Jordains & sir Bretel Sir Arthour wiþ hert lel For loue of Ygerne fre, Her leuedi þat hadde ybe; His men þo þai bicomen swiþe, To help him vp deþe & liue. Þis barouns & eke Merlin Wenten to þe bischopes in & al him teld fair & ?erne, Hou Arthour was bi?eten of Ygerne; Þe bischop þonked god so gode, Þat he was of þe kinges blode. Merlin seyd: “Listen meruaile: ?ou is comand strong bataile; Kinges sex at þis fest Þer schul arere michel chest, Whare fore ?e schul þan wite wel Boþe in iren & in stiel & loke, þat ichon held wiþ oþer, As ich man schal wiþ his broþer; For ich ?ou bihot, al þe honour Schal bileue wiþ ?ou & wiþ Arthour.” Þar þai biheten, þat non nold Oþer fail for no gold; Þe bischop seyd, his helping He schuld haue in al þing. What helpeþ it make tale long? Þai hem poruaid alle among Swiþe redi alle þing, Þat schuld to þat coroning. Mirie it is in time of June, When fenel hongeþ abrod in toun; Violet & rose flour Woneþ þan in maidens bour. Þe sonne is hot, þe day is long, Foules make miri song. King Arthour bar coroun In Cardoile, þat noble toun. King Lot, þat spoused Belisent, Com to þis coronment, He held þe lond of Lyoneis, Man wel strong & curteys, Wiþ fiue hundred noble kni?tes, Hardi & strong & leue to fi?tes. King Nanters com, god it wot, Þat held þe lond of Garlot, Swiþe noble man & wi?t, & wele couþe fende him in fi?t; He hadde yspoused Blasine, Arthours soster fair & fine; Seuen hundred kni?tes, y telle þe, He brou?t wiþ him of meyne, Of noble destrers & stede, Þat swiþe gode were at nede. King Vrien com þer to, Þe þridde suster hadde, al so; Þe lond of Gorre he held, ywis, He was ?ong man of noble pris, .xx. þousand he brou?t & fiue, No better kni?tes nere oliue. Þer com ?ete king Carodas; Þe king of Strangore he was, A swiþe mi?ti man of mounde & kni?t of þe tabel rounde; Þei he fer hadde yride, .vi. hundred kni?tes he brou?t him mide, Þat wele couþe juste in feld Wiþ stef launce vnder scheld. ?ete þer com king Yder, King of þe marche, of gret pouwer, Wiþ him he brou?t þritti score Wi?t kni?tes him bifore. Þer com king Angvisant, King he was of Scotlant; Of al þe sex he was richest, Of grete power & ?ongest; .v. hundred he brou?t wiþ him, ywis, Wi?t & strong kni?tes & al Scottis; & mani oþer bi souþe & bi est Þider com to þat fest. King & baroun, y ?ou say, Welcomed hem wiþ gret noblay; Biforn hem al þe bischop Brice Arthour crouned & dede þe office. Þo þe seruise ydon was, To mete þai turned her pas; Þai founde al redi cloþ & bord, Vp first ?ede þe hei?est lord; Men hem serued of gret plente, Mete & drink of gret deynte. Þer was venisoun of hert & bors, Swannes, pecokes & botors; Of fesaunce, pertris & of crane Þer was plente & no wane; Þer was piment & clare To hei?e lordinges & to meyne; Þai hadden al so noble seruise, So ani man couþe devise. Þo þai hadde yeten alle, Hei?e & lowe in þe halle, To ?euen ?iftes, sir Arthour aros, To hei?e men of grete los, & to haue of hem vmage, So it was ri?t & her vssage. As he was fair doinde þis, King Lot, king Nanters & oþer of priss Of his ?iftes spite hadden & his coroun anon wiþradden. Vp þai sterten wiþ gret bost, Euerich king wiþ al his ost, & seyd, an herlot for no þing No schuld neuer ben her king, & þou?t wiþ gret deshonour For to misdo sir Arthour. Ac Arthour men bitven þrest, Forþ com Merlin in þat chest & seyd, he nas harlot non, Ac nobler þan her ani on; Þer he teld al hem bifore, Hou Arthour was bi?eten & bore; Þe wisemen of þat lond Þonked Iesu Cristes sond, Þat her king schuld ben Of Vterpendragouns stren. Þe barouns seyd to Merlin: “He was founde þurch wiching þin: Traitour,” þai seyd, “verrament, For al þine enchauntement No schal neuer no hores stren Our king no heued ben, Ac he schal sterue ri?t anon!” Toward þe king & gun gon. Þe king was armed swiþe wel, & alle his frende in iren & stiel O?ain wiþstonden nobliche & al out driuen, sikerliche, Wiþ swerdes & kniues sone anon Out of halle þe kinges fon; Þe sex kinges were wel worþe & al her barouns sworen her oþe, No schuld þai neuer tviis eten, Er þai of Arthour were awreken, & swiþe telt her pauiloun A litel wiþ outen Cardoil toun. Þe bischop stode on þe castel wal & gan to preche to hem alle & seyd, Arthour was kinges stren. Of king bi?eten & born of quen; Þe king it wist in his liue, Blisced his child & bad him þriue & tok him to sir Antour To norice wiþe gret honour; ?if þai wisten nei?er blod, To make him king, it nar nou?t gode; “Ac, for he is king & kinges sone, Y cors al mididone His enemis wiþ Cristes mouþe, Bi est, bi west, bi norþ & souþe!” & ‘prut!’ þai seyden euerichon. Merlin went adoun anon & Arthours frende anon ri?t He told, hei?e & lowe, y pli?t; Four þousand among hem he fond, Hardi & noble & wi?t of hond, Ac alle it were, for soþe, fotmen, Bot fitene score & ten; Þe oþer were so gret rout, Þat þai wrei?e þe cuntre about. Merlin bad hem no þing drede: “Bot alle doþ bi mi rede!” Wiþ him þai went to þe gate anon. Wele atired euerichon. Merlin made enchauntement & kest gret encumberment Into þe pauilonis, wild fer, Þat brent bri?t so candel cler, & seyd to hem euerichon: “Now sle swiþe ?our fon!” Forþ þai went on hors gode To þe pauilouns, þat on fer stode, & on her fomen smiten anon; O liue þai reften mani on; Wiþ scharpe speres & swerdes kene Tventi score & fiftene O liue dawe þai brou?ten þere, Er þai wist, where þai were, For her witt was o way go For þe fer, þat brent so, & þe oþer her wit binam fulliche, Þat com on hem so sodanliche; Þer were so fele, naþeles, Þat litel sen þe slau?ter wes; Ac þurch his encumbrement Þai flowen alle, verrament, Til þai com fer oway, A mile þennes in o valay; Þer wiþstode þis sex kinges O?ai Arthour wiþ fi?tinges; & her folke wenten o?en, Mo þan ten þousand of men, Fram þis contek þat were ascaped, Sore adrad & awaþed. Þe kinges gadred hem to gider alle & seyd, gret schame hem was bifalle, Þat Arthour wiþ a litel punay Hadde ydriuen hem oway. Euerich to oþer þus made his mon, ?if þai were of Arthour on Awreken, alle þai hadde wonne; Alle þai swore bi mone & sonne, Hye schulden abigge þat ich striif, & went o?ain als biliif. Nanter, þe king of Garlot, Biforn he went, god it wot; He was a wele limed kni?t, Hardi & strong & wise in fi?t; A stef launce he bar an hand, Wiþ spores he smot his stede strong; Arthour sei?e, where he cam, A stef launce anon he nam, His fet in þe stiropes he strei?t, Þe stirop tobent, þe hors aquei?t; Þe stede he smot & he forþ glode, O?aines þe king Nanters he rode; Nanters him mett amid þe feld & hitt Arthour on þe schelde, Þat his launce gan to riue & tobrast on peces fiue. Arthour smot so Nanters þo, Þat his scheld brak atvo, & of his hors so him cast, Þat al mast his nek tobrast; Þo king Lot sei?e þis, Hou his nevou was feld, ywis, — He was on of þe strongest man Of al þis lond an for an — A launce he tok of gret valour & smot his stede o?ain Arthour; Euerich gan oþer wiþ launces take, Þat al to peces þai gun crake; Wiþ so gret ire to gider þai mett, Þat her bodis to gider stet. So astoned was king Lot, He lese his sadel, god it wot, & ouer þe croupe of his stede To grounde he fel, þat he gan blede; Arthour aforced him to dere, Ac michel folk com him to were; Þer come swiþe michel route, To slen Arthour, al aboute; Arthour drou? his swerd anon, Þat he drou? out of þe ston; A kni?t he toke wiþ þe egge, Þat him clef heued & rigge Into þe sadel, so seyt þe bok. Al he hirt, þat he toke; So sore he leyd on al aboute, Þat þai his dintes gun doute. Þis to kinges weren arisen, Þat were first of him agrisen; Þai & her feren four Wiþ four launces smiten Arthour Al at ones, þat was no glewe, & Arthour stede adoun þrewe, Þe king bi neþen, þe stede aboue: For soþe, sir Arthour was a swowe. Sir Antour al þis ysay, Bretel, Vlfin & sir Kay; Þai com swiþe to þis rideing, Forto helpen her king; Kay ful ri?t bigan to bere To king Angvisaunt a spere; He smot him þurch out þe scheld & his hauberk felefeld, & þurch his scholder an ellen long, & of his hors to grounde he þrong, & ?ete he feld, verrament, King Carodas wiþ þat dent: Þat was a dint of gret mounde, Þat tvay kinges þrewe to grounde! Vlfin & Nanters met þo, Þat her launces brosten atvo; To gider wiþ bodis þai metten, Þat boþe to grounde þai stetten; Þe hors hem lay anoward, Þat hem þou?t chaunce hard. Antor wiþ launce þe king Yder To grounde bar of his destrer; Bretel & king Vrien Her launces brust hem bitven. Þer whiles king Lot wiþ gret rout, To sle Arthour he was about. Kay, his steward, ysei?e þis; He was nei?e of his witt, ywis; Wiþ his swerd he gan him stere, His ?ong lord for to were; Wiþ pure strengþe of swerdes dint King Lot he feld, verrament, & was about, him to slen, Ac oþer stirt hem bitven. Þer kidde Kay, þat he was wi?t, For he no feined neuer of fi?t, Til þat Arthour, y ?ou pli?t, Was opon his stede di?t; & þo he was opon his stede, Wiþ swerd he gan about rede; Sum he binam scholder & arm & sum þe liif, it nas non harm; Non no durst abide more His stroke, for he smot so sore. Her ?e schul vnderstond, Þat men o fot of þis lond Helden wiþ king Arthour & dede him wel gret honour, Wiþ axes, staues, & wiþ bowe Dede so, þat alle þe oþer flowe, & þis kinges flowen also; Arthour after hem gan to go, & so he rode, wel fele he feld, Þat no more no tale teld. He ouertok þe king Yder & wold him heued wiþ his swerd cler; Ac a litel forbi he smot, His hors he hit, god it wot, Þe nek he karf adoun to grounde: Doun fel Yder, bi godes mounde. O?ain turned þo kinges fiue & halp him oway wiþ þe liue; Ac ich ?ou swere, in þat rideing Þai lau?t woundes wel sore biteing. Yder þai keuerd, naþeles, & þo he brou?t on hors wes, Þai flowen al so swiþe anon, As her steden mi?ten gon, & swore al wiþ wordes flegge, King Arthour it schuld abigge. King Arthour þo went o?en, To gider he gadred al his men & departede wiþ hem þe tresour, Þat he wan wiþ gret honour; & þo he þonked þe king of glorie, Þat him hadde ?ouen þe victorie, To ouercomen his fomen. In to Cardoil he went o?en & held fest noble & gent Wiþ his meyne, verrament; Al, þat euer wald þider gon, Curteyseliche were ressaiued anon; Þis fest last fourteni?t, Þat was riche & noble, a pli?t. Þo þe fest was ydo, Merlin com þe king to; To Londen he bad him hei?e & þer schewe his curteisie, & when he com þer, saunfayl, He wold him schewe gret conseil, Ac nou?t, ar he had fest ymade To al þe lond & made ful glade. King Arthour dede his consey! & went to Londen, saunfail, Where þe king, sir Arthour, Was afong wiþ gret honour. Sone after seyn Jones misse Þe king lete bidden more & lesse Into Londen to his fest; Swiche he made & held onest Þurch þe conseyl of Merlin; His seriauntes þo þurch him, Merlin tok to ich mester, Þat slei?e were & of power. Þo drou? bi half þe clerk Merlin Þe king Arthour & eke Vlfin & Bretel & sir Antour & Kay, þe steward of valour, & seyd: “Listen to me now, For soþe, ichil telle ?ou: .xi. kinges & doukes on Han ysworn, Arthour to slon; Swiche is her parlement Now in þe marche, verrament; O?aines hem ?e no haue no mi?t, Bot ?e hauen help to fi?t; Y wil ?ou telle, what do ?e mote, ?if ?e wil finden bote: Mi lord Vterpendragon Wan vnder him þe king Ban & his broþer Bohort al so; No better bodis no mowe go, Þai were sworn to Vter, mi lord: To hem ich rede sende word, To lesse Breteine, for it is nede, Þat Vterpendragon is dede; ?e mot hem sigge, verrament, Þat he vnto þis parlement Wiþ outen abod wel swiþe come, To don vmage Arthour, his sone; Þai wil comen anon, y wot, & help þe o?ain king Lot & elles where wiþ her power, ?ou worþ to hem wel gret mister Her afterward, par ma fay, Ichil ?ou tel som day. Þis message, sir Vlfin, Þou most bere bi conseil min, & þi fere schal be sir Bretel; Loke, ?e ben atired wel Wiþ gode armes, on gode stede, Þer to ?ou worþ a litel nede, Ar ?e comen o?ain to ous: Now hei?eþ ?ou for loue of Jesus!” Al þis hem liked wel, & sir Vlfin & sir Bretel Wele hem atired, sikerliche, & went forþ wel hastiliche. Þo þai com þe se bi?ounde, A gret wildernisse þai founde Bitven Fraunce & Breteyne, Þai sei?e mani mounteyn & pleine. Þo þai sei?e a litel hem abone Seuen kni?tes yarmed come, Of wiche to her steden smiten & to hem ward gun priken Wiþ loude cri, & bad hem ?eld; Bretel tok his launce & scheld, Þat o kni?t sone he mett & wiþ his scharp launce him gret; He bar him þurch þe þrote anon, Þat doun he fel ded so ston. Þat oþer he mett o?ainward, A dint he ?af him so hàrd, Þe launce ran þe brini þurch, Þe kni?t fel ded in a forwe; In his falling brast þe spere, Bretel bar it no ferþere. Oþer to þer come glide, Vlfin gan o?ain hem ride Opon a stede stef & strong Wiþ a launce gret & long; Þat on he bar þurch scheld & hat, Þat neuer seþþen mete no at; Þe oþer o?ain Vlfin brac his spere, Ac he no mi?t Vlfin dere; Vlfin him ?aue a dint of wo Þurch out þe membre & sadel also; Stede & kni?t ouerþrewe anon; Þe kni?t brast his nek bon, Vlfines launce tobrac. Þe þre come þo gret rac; Þe oþer foure, forto wreken Þe þre, gun her launces breken & her noiþer hirt nou?t; Bretel kidde, þat he was au?t, His werd he drou?, þat on he hit, His heued fram þe bodi he kit. Þat oþer oftoke sir Vlfin & so him hit on þe bacin, Þat he him cleue to þe toþ, So ous seyt þe Brout, for soþ. Þe oþer kni?t, her lord þat was, Wel swiþe went o?ain his pas; ?if he abod ani longere, Wele he sei?e, it was his lere. Þis ich kni?tes four & þre Wiþ Claudas hadde ybe, Wiþ Claudas hadde werred o?an Þe king Bohort & þe king Ban; Claudas was þo ouercome Priueliche & went to Rome, Him to puruay sum socour, To wreke him of his deshonour. Þer while þo kni?tes, cert, Were ywent in to desert, To libben bi her robrie; Ac þer hem fel gret vilanie. Þer after Vlfin forþ him rode & eke Bretel, wiþ outen abod; No lete þai neuer jornaying, Til þai com to Ban, þe king; & þo he com bifor Ban, Þus his wordes he bigan: “Jesus Crist, heuen king, Þ loke, sir Ban, þe king, & þi meine so gent & fre, Þat ich here about þe se! Þe barouns of Breteine þe more Tiding þe sent, þat reweþ hem sore: Vterpendragon, þi lord, is ded & is departed þurch godes red; King is made his sone Arthour & þe greteþ wiþ gret honour & bad þe & þi broþer gent Com to his parlement, For to wite & vnderstond Of þe lawes of his lond!” King Ban wiþ noble cher Welcomed þo messanger & seyd, her wil do he wold & his broþer al so schold. Þe messangers þo he made Wele at ese; wiþ gret ferrade Bohort þer after swiþe he sent Bi on asent, & swiþe went In to þis lond wiþ mani fair, Forto se þe kinges air. In euerich toun fram Portesmouþe To Londen of gret valoure Men made song & hopines O?ain þe come of þis kinges. No was wonded for drie no wete, Þat in lond eueri strete Was bihonged, ich say for soþ, Wiþ mani pal & riche cloþ; Euerich man of ich mester Hem riden o?ain wiþ fair ater; In euerich strete damisels Karols ledden fair & fels. Þo þai were to court ycome, Þai were hendeliche welcome; Him selue þe king Arthour Hem com o?ain wiþ gret honour, Curteiseliche & hem gan calle & anon ledee hem to halle Wiþ her broþer Gvinbaut, Noble clerk, so dieu me saut; In þe sterres he was þe best deuine In al þe warld, wiþ outen Merlin. Þer atwot þe clerk Merlin At þe fest þe douke Vlfin & Bretel, þat was his felawe, Hou þai hadde þe kni?tes yslawe; Ac al þat euer herden þis, Wonder hadde þer of, ywis, Þat he told her bataile, & þer no com nou?t, saunfaile, & namliche Bohort & Ban & Gvinbaut, þe þridde man. Þere þo men mi?t yhere Þe queintise of þe spere, Of þe sonne, of mone & ster, When þe welken turned of herre, & of mani priue werk Bitven Merlin & Gvimbaut, þe clerk. Her after sone Merlin swore & sir Vlfin & sir Antore & sir Kay & sir Bretel Tofore þe king on o messel, Þat Arthour was Vter stren Bi Ygerne, þat was his quen. Þer afterward sone, for soþ, Þe kinges swore Arthour hold oþ & deden him also swiþe omage, So it was ri?t & vsage; & þo held Arthour fest, a pli?t, Þat last ful fourtenni?t; Of ich riches & deinte, Certes, þer was gret plente; Þo was þer made a turnament, Þat was swiþe noble & gent, Of bacheler & ?ong kni?t, Swiþe strong & swiþe wi?t. Þo, þat were of ?ond half, O?ain þo weren of þis half. Þe best was Lucan, þe boteler, A ?ong kni?t of grete power, Wiþ outen þe steward Kay, He was a kni?t of gret noblay; Grimfles, Maruc & Gumas, Ich of hem wel noble was; Placides & eke Driens, Holias & Graciens, Marlians & Flaundrius, Sir Meliard & eke Drukius, & al so Breoberuis, Þese born oway þe priis; Noman no herd of fairer Turnament no nobler. Þo al þis mirþe was ydo, Merlin com þe king to & to hem seyd: “Bieu segnours, ?e ben yswore to king Arthours, ?e mot boþe him ridee To Leodegan of Carmalide; For bi mi rede he schal spouse Gvenour, his douhter precious; Sche is boþe fair & wise, Of al þe lond sche berþ þe priis; Hir fader Leodegan Is a swiþe noble man, Ac king Rion, wiþ outen lesinges, Him werreþ opon wiþ tventi kinges: Þer ?e mot him help, ywis, Forto win los & pris!” “Certes,” quaþ king Ban, þe gent, “Þer to we han gret talent, ?if king Claudas in our lond Þer whiles nold ous wait no schond; For he ous haþ werred long Wiþ vnri?t & michel wrong.” “Nay,” quaþ Merlin, “drede ?ou nou?t: ?if þou lesest þer fore ou?t, For þe mountaunce of pani on Þou schalt han hundred o?an!” “To þat couenaunt,” quaþ Ban, þe king, “We beþ redi in al þing, Anon to go wiþ king Arthour, To his manschipe & his honour!” Merlin seyd: “Bi seyn Jon, Arst ?e mot anoþer don: .xi. kinges & a douke Beþ hiderward, wiþ outen dout, To slen Arthour & his man, In þe forest of Rokeingham; Þere ?e mot help him were Vnder scheld wiþ swerd & spere!” “Allas!” quaþ Ban, “for Cristes sond, We no haue no folk of our lond!” Quaþ Merlin: “So god me spede, No schal ?ou faile non at nede!” Þer it was forboden anon, Ich man bi way for to gon, Noiþer mile tene no fiue, Opon pain of her liue; Þis was don for non oþer þing, Bot for a spies and waiteing, Where þurch alle weren yhent, Þat fram þe barouns weren ysent, & non com o?ain, verrament, To wray þe kinges parlement. ?ete Merlin went to Rokingham, Vlfin & oþer wiþ him he nam, Mani pauilouns & telt, & dede þer in flesches & selt & oþer store of mele & win, & tok it to lok Sir Vlfin & bad, he no schuld lete passe Noiþer þe more no þe lasse, Þat mi?t bere ani tiding To þe barouns of her king No of his parlement, No þai no deden, verrament. Þo ?ede Merlin to Ban, þe king, & tok of him his kinges ring, & to king Bohort al so; To lasse Breteine he ?ede þo Ouer þe se in on ni?t, Fele iurnes, y ?ou pli?t, For in þe Brut ich it lerne, To Leonce of Paerne, Þat was kinges Banes steward, A wiseman wiþ hor bard, & to Fairen, wel noble kni?t, Bohortes steward þat was, a pli?t, & schewed hem her lordes ring & bad, þai schuld him socour bring. Leonce and eke Fairen To gider brou?ten her men, Fourti þousand þat were teld, On stede in armes swiþe beld. .xv. þousende þai leten þere, Her lond to kepen & to were, And .xxv. þousend wiþ him toke, So we finden in þe boke, Wiche ouer se þe clerk Merlin Brou?t & loged bi Vlfin. To kinges court he gan þo fare & asked, ?if þai weren ?are, For her fomen were nei?ehond. King Ban seyd: “For godes sond, Whi no hastow brou?t me socour?” Merlin seyd: “Al rady to ?our honour!” Þo þai di?t hem, swain & kni?t, & wenten þider þat ich ni?t. Þo þai þider weren ycome, Þai ordeind & teld her þrome; Fourti þousand men þai founde, To batail men of gret mounde. Michel ioie made king Ban & Bohort al so of her man; For þai deden þere finde .xxv. þousinde. Arthour hadde þousandes fiftene & na mo, al so y wene, For al þe barouns & þe kinges Were in þe marche, wiþ outen lesinges, Wiþ al þe men, y ?ou say, Þat þai mi?t hem puruay. To slen Arthour, lasse & more, Al þai hadde to gider swore; Ac, for soþe, non of hem No wist of Arthoures men; Ac we finden in þe boke, Þat þai hadde þer bispoke, On Arthour wiþ her route Þai wold happen al aboute & hem to taken in þe forest, When þai sei?en time best. To þis tresoun for to don Com þe king Clarion, Þat was king of Norþ-Humberlond, Wiþ seuen þousand kni?tes strong. King Brangores, þat held Strangore, Þider com, bi godes ore, & brou?t wiþ him fiue þousand kni?t, In bataile þat were strong & wi?t. Cradelman, king of Norþ-Wales, Hardi man & wise of tales, Sex þousend þider he brou?t, Of liue or deþe þat litel rou?t. A king þer com of an hundred kni?tes, His name was cleped bi ri?tes, For he no ladde neuer lasse rout, Þan an hundred kni?tes, about; He was king wel fer bi norþ, A wel strong man & michel worþ; Kni?tes he brou?t four þousinde, Men no mi?t non better finde. King Lot, þat held londes tvo, Leonis & Dorkaine al so, He brou?t seuen þousend kni?tes, Swiþe hardi & stronge in fi?tes. ?ete þer com king Carodas, Þat of þe rounde table was; Seuen þousand he brou?t also; No better kni?tes no mi?t go. Nanters, þe king of Garlot, Þider com, god it wot, Vp Arthour, þat was wroþ & grim, Sex þousinde he brou?t wiþ him, Stronge kni?tes & noble, saunfaile, Þat wise & hardi were in bataile. ?ete þer come king Vrien Wiþ sex þousand of wi?t men, Wele atired on gode destrers, Wiþ outen fotmen & squiers. ?ete þer com king Yder Wiþ fiue þousand of gret power. ?ete þer com king Angvisaunt, Þe riche king of Scotlaunt, Wiþ sex þousende kni?tes beld Boþe in boun & eke in feld. ?ete þer come þe douc Sestas, Erl of Canbernic he was; Arundel was hoten þo Cambernic, wiþ outen no; He brou?t wiþ him þousandes fiue, Non better nere oliue. Alle þese priueliche To Rokingham com, sikerliche, & loged hem in þe forest, Stille, wiþ outen ani chest, Wiþ al, þat þai procoure mi?t, Boþe of baroun & of kni?t. Ac Arthour was wel stilly Wiþ his folk nei?e hem bi; Noiþer baroun no king Nist nou?t of his being. Þe ferþ ni?t after her soiour Merlin bad þe king Arthour & Bohort & king Ban, Hem atiren & her man & com wiþ him anon ri?tes & kiþe, ?if þai were noble kni?tes. Bope in iren & in stiel Þai hem armed swiþe wel & wiþ Merlin went, y say, Ar day þre mile way. In þis time Lot, þe king, In bed was in gret meteing; Him þou?t, water, winde & rain In her teld was hem, o?ain, Her pauilouns ouerþrewe þe þonder. He ofwoke & had wonder; His sweuen he teld his feren hard, Þai him axed, whiderward Him þou?t, þat his sweuen bar; Þe soþe anon he teld þar. Þiderward wel swiþe an hye Þai senten spies, forto aspie. Þis spies anon forþ stetten & wiþ Merlin sone metten & wiþ Arthour, king of los; Of þat meteing hem agros. Merlin hem sei?e & bad hem bide; Fleand oway þai gun ride & euer grad: “Traisoun, traisoun!” Þe oþer her of herd þe soun & hem atired, verrament; Ac Merlin cast enchauntment, Þat her pauilouns, on & alle, To þe grounde gun to falle, &, so ich in þe boke yfinde, Þe mest part he made blinde. King Arthour & Bohort & Ban Opon hem smiten onan, & eke alle her ferrede Wiþ hors fete on hem trede, Wiþ speres stong, wiþ swerdes korwe Ten þousende kni?tes bi þe morwe, Ar ani of hem mi?t hem stere Oþer sen abouten, hem to were. Ac, naþeles, þis .xi. kinges Flowen o way wiþ michel genge A litel þennes in til a lowe; A loude horn þai gun blowe, Of her kni?tes & gaderd hem so To gider þritti þousende & mo. Ich king had to his dale Þre þousand gret & smale, Her hors girten & sadels ri?t & made hem redi forto fi?t. On þe hille þai gun ten, Arthour & his folk to sen; Þo sei?e þai seuen baners, Of whiche Lucan, þe boteler, Of þe first maister was, For swiþe hardi man he was. Grifles ladde þe secounde, A wi?t man of gret mounde; Þe þridde folc ladde Bretel. Strong kni?t & doinde wel. Þe ferþ baner ladde Kay, Þe kinges steward of noblay. Þe fift baner ladde Vlfin, A noble baroun gode afin. Ich hadde of þis to his baner Þre þousand of gret power. Arthour on hors sat stef so stok & gouerned þe seuend flok & ladde wiþ him four þousinde Wi?t men & wel doinde. Þe oþer no mi?t ben ykidde, Bi hinden hem þai weren yhidde; King Lot, king nanters & king Vrien & king Carodas wiþ his men, Þis foure bi hinde were & lete þe oþer al forþ fare, & in þe sonnes vpriseing Bigan, certes, þis rideing. Þer mi?t men se þe baners roten, Þe stedes forþ wel ?ern schoten; Þo þai first oþer metten, Ich oþer wip launces gretten; Mani in sadles held hem stille, & mani al so of hors felle; Mani brac his spere þare, ÞMani oþer þurch out bar. Kai þan felled þe king Yder Wiþ his spere of his destrer; Þe king of hundred kni?tes Kay doun feld anon ri?tes. Kay vp stirt & king Yder, A fot fou?ten wiþ swerdes cler; On boþe half so com her men & swiþe stirten hem bitven. Þer come Lucan, þe boteler, & bar Eustas of his destrer; Eustas, þe douke of Arundel, Bi Yder stode & werd him wel. Grifles feld þe king Clarion; Þe king of hundred kni?tes com & hit Grifles bi þe side; Of his stede he gan doun glide; Vp strit Grifles & stode bi Kay & fau?t so a kni?t of noblay. Forþ com Vlfin & eke Lucan & feld king Cradelman, & wiþ oþer kni?tes mo Riden he þese kni?tes to, Þe douke Grifles & þe steward Kay On hors þai brou?t, þar ma fay; Þo þai were mounted, y sigge, a pli?t, Þai kedden her noble mi?t: Þan þe king of þe hundred kni?tes Kay doun feld anon ri?tes, & þre kni?tes al a rawe He binam þer her liif dawe. Arthour wiþ his mi?ti hand Feld king Brangors & king Anguisaunt. Þo were a fot seuen kinges, Gret slau?ter was at her rideinges, Þat þai no mi?t nou?t keuer her destrers For her alder powers. King Lot & king Carodas & Nanters, þat bi hinde was, & eke þe king Vrien Wiþ tvelf þousand of strong men, Þe hors of baundoun lete þai frem & come flingand wiþ al her men: So Arthours folk þai metten & of her steden mani stetten: In þat ich hard meteinges Al þai socourd her kinges & brou?ten hem on her steden; Þe etter þo þai mi?t speden. Þer wer fele of hors yfeld & kni?tes yslawe vnder scheld; Ac þer schewed king Arthour At þat batayl gret vigour; Of his men mani feld ware, Now he was here, now he was tare, & chalanged his men bi ri?t & wi?tlich bigan, for hem to fi?t; Wiþ his swerd of gode egge Sum he clef to þe rigge, & sum he smot þe nek atvo, & sum he smot þe schulder fro. Þe oþer kinges were wi?t also, Arthours fok þai deden wo; .xxx. þousand, for soþe y wene, Fou?ten þer o?ain sextene; Lucan, Grifles & king Arthour, Vlfin, Bretel & sir Antour, Þis ich seuen, saunfail, Þe cark hadde of Þe batayl. Þe folk descomfit hadde men sen, No hadde her mi?t þe better ben; Ac in al þis surcarking Merlin com to Ban, þe king, & seyd: “Sir, time it is, Þou help king Arthour, ywis!” Al so swiþe þan Ban, þe king, Went forþ wiþ outen letting. Farien, a kni?t of gret power, He was douke of þe first baner; Maruc loked þe secounde, A kni?t of swiþe gret mounde; Of þe þridde maister was Þe noble king Belias; Þe ferþ ledde Bleoberiis, A baroun of wel oble pris; Þe fif ladde Gracian, Strong baroun & noble man; Þes fiue, so y finde, Led of men fiftene þousinde; Þer ich of hem hastiliche Went hem forþ, hardiliche. Bohort afterward cam Wiþ four þousand of noble man; In þis world wele to fi?t No were yhelden non better kni?t. Al so þai maden þis wailing, Þe oþer com on hem smiteing Wiþ her speres & feld to grounde Mani, þat þai þere founde. In þis time king Lot Went out of þe plas, god it wot, & king Nanters & king Vrien Wiþ mani noble of her men, & king Carodas, þe wi?t, & king of þe hundred kni?t. Þese so michel pite sei?en, Þat þai weþe wiþ her ei?en For þe sle?ster of her man & sore þe dede of king Ban, & Bohort al so, his broþer: Þere no schuld go no noþer; Adoun þai li?t & her hors girten, Wiþ outen stirop þer in stirten; Euerich of hem nome in his hond A launce boþe stef & strong; King Nanters, king Lot, king Karodas, Þis men armed wiþ gret ras; King Ban þai hitten alle at ones, Adoun þai þrewe him on þe stones; King of þe hundred kni?tes & king Vrien, King Bohort þai riden o?en & hitten him boþe at a dent & feld his stede, verrament; Ac Ban vp stirt & Bohort al so & wele hem wered o fot bo; Þe oþer hem were about to dere, Ac manliche þai gun hem were. King Arthour sei?e doun king Ban, Swiþe wo him was for þan; His stede he smot þider anon, A kni?t, þat was about, king Ban to slon. On þe helme he smot, for soþ, Þurch helme & palet to þe toþ & pelt doun þat bodi dede & tok þat stede gode at nede. King Ban þan þurch fine mi?t On þat stede lepe, a pli?t; Þo he þe stede was opon, He ?aue a nedel of his fon. Anoþer king Arthour hitte, Þe bodi to þe nauel he kitte Fro þe scholder, y tel ?ou; It was a dint of gret vertu; Arthour pelt adoun þat buke, Þat hors he lad Bohort, þe douke; Þo þai on hors seten boþe, Þai were aschamed & eke wroþ; So we finden on þe boke: Who þat ani of hem oftoke, Of liue no hadde þai no bote, Ac to þe deþ went, god it wot. What gette it, al to tellen here? Arthur & Ban & her fere So michel pople toforn hem slowe, Þat her enemis hem wiþdrowe & gun to fle to on brigge, Þat þai toforn dede ligge. Þer spac Morganor on hast, King Vriens sone o bast, — He was on of þe best kni?t, Þat mi?t held swerd in fi?t — He seyd: “Sir, listneþ alle: O our folk we moten calle Bi on horn, þat y schal blawe, Oþer þai worþ alle yslawe & destroied of our fon!” Þe kinges seyd: “Þat is wele don!” Morganor þo gan to blowe, Þat folk so gun his horn knowe, Swiftlich al þai gunnen flen Þ to þe kinges socour ten. Þo þai comen to þe brigge, Ich on oþer gan to legge; Ac, al so wolf þe schip gan driue, Arthour smot hem after swiþe, & king Ban & her men Slou? of hem þousendes ten. Þer þai hadde mani slawe, Ac Merlin gan hem wiþdrawe & seyd, o?ain wende þai schold, Þe siluer to part & þe gold & mani oþer riche þinges, Þat þer hadde left þe riche kinges. Arthour þou?t gode afin Þe riche conseyl of Merlin: Þe oþer oway þai leten flen & gan o?ain wiþ his folk ten. Of gold, of siluer & noblesse Þai founden grete riches; Arthour it ?af Bohort & Ban & bad it part among her man; So þai deden wiþ gret honour To hem & to þe king Arthour. After þat gentil parting To Londen went Arthour, þe king, & king Bohort & king Ban & alle her noble man; Fourten ni?t Arthour held fest Swiþe noble & swiþe onest. Þo þe fest ydon was, Merlin teld Arthour þat cas; “Arthour,” he seyd þis þinges, “No drede þe nomore of þis kinges; Now þai han ymade it tou?, Sone hem worþ to don ynou?, Er þan com þe trinite. Ich wald ?iuen o cite, Wiþ þat þai hadde made acord & þat þou were made her lord, For here is comand to þis lond Gret hunger, & here gong Sex hundred Sarrazins, Forto awreke þe douke Angis; Þis lond þai comen al about, Of hem no þarf þe noþing dout; Her schal com a bachelrie, Of þe to haue cheualrie & of þe to ben made kni?t, & for þi lond þai wil fi?t; Þai schul don mani agrise, Of hem þi los schal arise, Þou schalt hem alle knowe wel & of þe kinges wite eueridel. Þai schullen hauen in her lond Of wer to don ful her hond; & ich ?ou sigge, Bohort & Ban. Sendeþ hom al ?our man, ?our lond to loke & ouersen, Bot it swiþe fewe ben. Arthour schal alle his tounes Astore wiþ flesche & venisouns, Wiþ corn & mele & men strong, O?ain her fon to werre long; & þou, Arthour, me schalt abide Bitven Inglond & Carmelide In þe toun of Brekenho, Til ich me self þe com to!” Þis was do, wiþ outen doute: Arthour his tounes stored aboute Wiþ corn, mele, flesche & fische & wiþ men strong, ywis. Þe douke þo, wiþ outen fable. Of Cardoil hadde ben constable; Of Londen, bi Merlines rade, He was þo constable ymade. Leonce he sent hom of Paerne. Ban & Bohort swiþe ?erne & þe douke al so Pharien & þe baroun Gracien, Wiþ her ost þe lond to loke, So we finden on þe boke. King Arthour, Bohort & Ban Wele wiþ sex score of her man Went hem to Brekenho, So Merlin hem seyd to, Bitven Inglond & Carmelide, Merlines com forto abide, Þat þo fro hem was ywent, Þai nist whider, verrament. Þo þai hadde þere a while abiden, On a day out þai riden & sei?e com bi on lowe An eld cherl wiþ aruwe & bowe; Þe cherl bent his bowe sone & smot a doke mididone, & wiþ a bolt afterward Anon he hitt a maulard. Þis foules he nam þo, O?ain þe king he gan go; Arthour him asked, as y ?ou telle, ?if he wold þo foules selle. Þis old man seyd, par ma fay, He wold hem ?iue for monay; Þe king him axed, so most he liue, Hou he wold þe foules ?iue; Þeld man seyd: “Sir king, Nou?t þou schust make hucking, Ac þou schust hote hem bere forþ & tviis ?iue me þe worþ, For ich þe wold soner ?iue Þis to foules, so mot y liue, Þan þou a pani of þi gold, Þat liþ bidoluen depe in mold!” Wiþ þis word, þe foules to, Sir Kay he tok hem bo. To þat eld seyd Arthour: “Who teld þe of mi tresour?” “Certes,” he seyd, “þe clerk Merlin, For swiþe late y spac wiþ him!” Þe king nold him leue nou?t, Þeld man seyd, him no rou?t, “For, king,” he seyd, “þou hast of me, & y no haue nou?t of þe!” Bretel & Vlfin him vnderstode & seyd anon wiþ milde mode: “Sir, god þe ?eld þis foules to: ?iftes þou hast him ?euen mo, & ?ete þou schalt wiþ godes mi?t Mo presantes & ?iftes him di?t!” Þer þai wisten bi Vlfin, Þat þis eld was Merlin. Merlin him schewed to king Arthour, & he him kist wiþ gret honour, & Bohort & Ban & oþer swiþe Of his come weren bliþe. A damisel of gret valour Was þo comen to king Arthour, To knowe him lord & don omage, Þat sche no hadde afterward damage; & alle hir kni?tes deden al so, Þat wiþ hir were comen þo; Li?anor þat may was hot, Erl Siweinis douhter, god it wot. Þo Arthour hir hadde ysei?e, Bi hir he wald haue ylei?e; So he dede þurch Merlin, A child he bi?at hir in, Þat wex seþþen of gret mounde & kni?t of þe table rounde. Þere þai soiournud euerichon, Til þat lenten were half agon. Lete we hem þer stille be & of þe kinges telle we, .xi., þat flowen are, Hou þai bicomen & whare. In time of winter alange it is: Þe foules lesen her blis, Þe leues fallen of þe tre, Rein alangeþ þe cuntre; Maidens leseþ here hewe, Ac euer hye louieþ, þat be trewe. Þe kinges, þat descomfit ware, Al day & al ni?t hadde yfare On hors, armed, wiþ gret hete, Wiþ outen drink, wiþ outen mete, Til þai com to Norhant, A fair cite of gode waraunt. Norham was þat time, y wene, A prout cite & strong & kene; Ich ?ou telle at on word: King Vriens was þerof lord. Þis kinges alle þider comen ware & hadden sorwe & gret care, For her kni?tes were so yslawe & her kin brou?t o liue dawe; Swiche diol þai hadden dayes to, Nold þai mete to mirþe do. Vp him stirt Bandamagu. A kni?t of gret vertu, & seyd: “Kinges, leteþ ben: ?our diole is rewþe for to sen; ?e habbeþ frendes fer & wide, To hem ?e schulleþ nouþe ride & ?our diol to hem speke, Þurch whom ?e worþ awreke!” Þurch his speche comfort þai nome, Þe þridde day & to gider come, & euerich oþer ?aue swiche solas, So þai mi?ten in þas cas; Þat day þai maden hem at aise, To bed ani?t þai ?eden in paise. Þe ferþ day euerich aros, & sone days hem agros, For to hem com a messanger & gret hem wiþ rewelich chere & seyd, in to Cornnewaile Sarrazins were comen, saunfaile, & hadde nei?e strued al þat lond Wiþ wilde fere & wiþ brond & þe lond of Dorkaine also Ystroied & don michel wo; Nambires þai hadde bilay & destrued al þe cuntray Boþe wiþ fer & wiþ sword; Spard þai noiþer knaue no lord. Þer was so michel pople of hem, Þat tellen hem no mi?t men. Þo þe kinges yherd þis, In her hertes nas no blis; Al her flesche bigan to quake, So þe feuer hem had ytake; Ich of hem seyd: ‘allas!’ Þat ani of hem ybore was. Þe wailing, þat þai made, To day no mi?t ich ful rade, Ac swiche sorwe made, a pli?t, Ich of hem fourtenni?t, Þat litel mete com hem among, Bot waileway & wepeing strong, At þe fourtenni?tes ende King Brangore wi?t & hende Com him forþ in to þe halle & ofsent his feren alle; To hem alle þan spak Brangori: “Yblisced be þe king of glorie Of his grace & of his sending! What helpeþ ous swiche morning? Fond we ous to bistere & our lond sum del to were: We no haue pouer Arthour o?en For king Bohort & king Ban No for Merlin, þe gode clerk, Þat can so michel schandliche werk; We no haue deserued, of Arthour To haue nonskinnes socour, To helpen ous o?ain Angys kende, Þat þenkeþ ous forto schende, & we haue ylorn our mi?t, Nou?t wiþ wrong, ac al wiþ ri?t, Þat wold haue our lord kende Yslawe þurch lore of þe fende. Of king Leodegan help worþ ous non, For of Yrlond þe king Rion Him haþ awerred to ?er & more Wiþ tventi kinges, bi godes ore, No of king Pelles of Listonei No worþ ous help, par ma fay, For þe ward of Pelleore, His broþer, liþ sike & sore & schel be seke, fort þe meruaile Of þe greal be don, saunfaile, No forþer of þe king Alain No worþ ous noiþer help no main, For he liþ sike & sike schal ben For þe best kni?t of stren: Y haue seyd, wherfore it is, Þat he bicom sike, ywis — No of þe king of þe Marais Nor Maga of Sorailes No may þer com help to ous, For him awerreþ Galaous, No of þe king Bremeins No of þe king Adameins No of þe king Clamadas No may ous com no solas, For alle hem werreþ Galeus, Þe riche king so vertouous. Lokeþ now, hou we may spede, For we habbeþ wel gret nede!” Þo bispac Cradelman, King of Norþ-Wales, a wise man: “Þe best conseil, þat y can: Part we alle our man, & hire we alle þo, Þat we wiþ catel may ago, & ich man wende to his cite, Þat we wene strangest be, & kepe we þe strait wais Ouer alle in þe cuntrays & robben hem her sustenaunce Wiþ skec, & don hem combraunce & waiten hem al þe qued, Þat we mowe, bi mi red!” Þo bispac sir Lot, þe king: “Gode ware al þis conseiling, Ac ich wot, when Arthour seþ, Þat we of þe payens awerred beþ, Anoþer half he wil ous anoie & wiþ schond ous destroie!” Þe king of þe hundred kni?t Seyd: “Drede ?ou nou?t, y ?ou pli?t: Arthour wiþ Bohort & Ban Beþ toward Leodegan & help him o?ain Rion & hem warnisen euerichon Boþe cite & castel Wiþ mete & men swiþe wel, Þat hem no stondeþ no doute Of þe payens no of her route; Of him no haueþ non drede, For it is soþe, þat ich ?ou sede; Mi conseyl is, ?e don anon, So þou seydest, king Cradelman!” Þis conseyl þai deden þo & senten after mani mo, Kni?tes, swaines, man, þat wold Winnen siluer oþer gold, For to loke, wiþ outen asoine, Al þe marches of Galoine & of Cornwaile þe pleines & eke þe place of Dorkains & of Gorre al so, ich say, & eke þe entres of Galeway. Alder first Yder, þe king, Þre þousand hadde of bileueing, Þat yslawe no were nou?t, O?aines Arthour þan þai fou?t, & .viii. þousand of purchas He hadde al so, bi godes gras, & to þis strong cite Nante, Wiþ alle þis men he wante, & ?ete he hadde þousandes þre Of þe cite, bi mi leute. Þis Ider loked wele þe wayes Wiþ his folk in þat cuntreys, & payens he ouercam Oft & her mete binam & so wele in armes dede, Þat men him blisced in eueri stede. King Nanters, þe wi?t man, So went forþ in to Hussidan, His owhen cite, þat was of priis, Wiþ þre þousand, him bileued, ywis, In þe bataile, þer he was, Wiþ seuen þousand of purchas, & fif þousand in toun he fond, Orped men & gode of hond. Þis loked wele þe paþes & þe paiens oft deden scaþes, Boþe o lif & eke tresour Þai dede þe paiens misauentour. King Lot went to Dorkaine Wiþ þre þousand bileued wiþ paine, Þer he was at þe bataile, & wiþ fiue þousand of purchas, saunfaile, & four þousand he fond in his toun, Wi?t men & of grete renoun; & ?ete for his wi?t pruesse & hendeschip & largesse Þre þousand after him come, Gode bataile forto done. .viii. þousand þo hadde Lot, Þat wele him holpe, god it wot, Þe waies & þe paþes ?eme & of þe Sarrains hem reme, & often deden hem gret greuaunce & robbed hem her sustenaunce. Þo went king Clarion To Norþ-Humberlond anon, To his cite, þat hete Arlende, Wiþ þre þousand, þat were hende, Þat him bileued at þat fi?t O?ain Arthour, þe gode kni?t. .viii. þousand he hadde of purchas, Þat wele deden in eueri plas; Þe wayes þai deden wele awayt & þe paþes, þat were strait, & oft deden þe Sarrazins Grete schame & grete pines. After went anon ri?tes, Þe king of þe hundred kni?tes, Aguigines was his name, He was a kni?t of gret fame; He went him to Malaot, A riche cite, god it wot; Þe cite on leuedis was & stode in a wel gret pas, Where þe Sarrazins com & ride; Þre þousand he brou?t him mide, Ascaped from deþes hond, Þat leuedi marched on his lond; Þer fore sche com to his socour & fond kni?tes of grete valour, Ynou? to loken her lond, & so þai deden wiþ mi?ti hond. After went Cradelman, To Norþ-Wales þat he cam Wiþ þre þousand of his kni?tes, Þat were ascaped fram þe fi?tes; He purchast seuen þousinde, So ich in þe boke yfinde; Four þousand he fond at hom, Þat were bilþe of his com, For vnneþe fram hem fiue mile Woned a wiche, hete Carmile; Hir broþer hi?t Hardogabran, A swiþe riche soudan; Of wichecraft & vilainie & eke of nigramancie Of þis warld sche couþe mast, Wiþ outen Arthours sone a bast; Morgein, for soþe, was hir name, & woned wiþ outen Niniame, Þat wiþ hir queint gin Bigiled þe gode clerk Merlin. Þis Carmile in þat cuntray Hadde a castel of gret noblay; Of þat castel hadde socour Þe Sarrazins & gret recour, Whar þurch þe king Cradelman Was soure carked & alle his man; Ac swiþe wele, noþelas, Þe marche he loked & eke þe pas; Ac Carmile, par ma fay, Bi Merlines liif day No mi?t do wiþ hir wicheing In Inglond non anoiing. King Brangore þo went forþ To Estrangore, wel fer bi norþ, & woned þat wiche bi side: Þe more noi?e him gan bitide; Þre þousinde wiþ him he nam, Þe slei?t þat were ascaped fram; Sex þousinde he hadde of purchas & fiue, of his cite þat was, Þat loked þe cuntray & often dede þe panimes tray. Þis Brangores of valour Ludranef douhter þemperour Bi þat time hadde yspoused, A leuedi gent & preciouse; Ac þe king of Hungri & of Blaske Hir hadde first to wiue ytake; Bi hir form husbounde Sche hadde a child of gret mounde, Þat was yhoten Sagremor, In ward wiþ þemperour; Þat was air of þemperie & of Blaske & of Hungrie. ?e schul here afterward, hou Segremor Com to kni?t of king Arthour, Where þurch þemperour, sikerliche, Him hadde ygraiþed richeliche & hadde him sent to Costentinenoble, To Inglond ward wiþ mani noble. ?ete went forþ king Carodas, Þat of þe rounde table was, To Galence, his cite, A cite riche of gret plente; Wiþ him he hadde þre þousand kni?t, Þat were ascaped fram þat fi?t, & þer he fond foure þousinde Noble kni?tes, so ich finde, & seuen þousand of gret powers He purchasced, on hei?e destrers, Þat wiþ swerd & launce & kniif Binomen mani painems her liif & wiþ skekes & wiþ fi?t Þe wayes loked wele, a pli?t. Þer after þe king Anguisaunt Went to Coranges in Scotland Wiþ fiue þousand gode kni?tes Alle ascaped fram þe fi?tes; Of purchas he hadde þousendes ten, Swiþe wele fi?tand men, Wiþ outen mani, þat he fond In his cite & in his lond. He nas bot tventi mile way Fram Nambire, þat was bilay Of mani þousand Sarrain, Where of he hadde mister fin, To fele kni?tes, him to helpe, To fi?t o?ain þe Sarrazin welpe; So þai deden wiþ chere bliþe Swiþe oft & mani siþe, On hem schoten bi wayes & paþes & dede þe Sarrains gret scaþes. Þo went Eustas to Arundel Wiþ þre þousand armed wel, Þat were ascaped fram þe batayle, Wiþ seuen þousand, sanfaile, Þat wele loked paþ & way Ouer al in þat cuntray. King Vriens bileued stille In Norham, sori & eke ille For depart of his felawes & for her men, þat weren yslawe; He hadde in alle þousandes ten, Boþe wi?t & hardy men, Þat anoied bi al her mi?t Þe Sarrazins bi day & ni?t. Now ?e schul vnderstond: Fif ?er þis last in Inglond, Þat no corn no was ysowe, Noiþer on doun no on lowe. Alle þis ich ?eres fiue Þis kinges þus ladde her liue Wiþ þat þai mi?t reue & robbe Of Sarrazins wiþ swerd & clobbe; Þe lowe folk in þe cuntray Were yslawe for nou?t al day, & alle yslawe hadde yben, No hadde sir Wawain to hem sen; Þat was þo a bacheler, Jolif & of strong power. Ac ar ich ?ou more þing Of paiems telle oþer king, Of Nanters sones & of his feren Noble þing ?e schullen yheren; His sone was hoten Galathin. Now listneþ wele for loue min Of Ygerne, þat ich er of spake, Hou Hoel hir hadde spoused to make; On hir he bi?at Blasine gent, & so he dede Belisent. King Nanters hadde spoused Blasine & Lot Belisent fair & dine. Y wil wele, þat ?e it wite: Nanters in Blasine hadde bi?ete A fair ?ong man, Galathin, Wi?t, hende & gentil afin. Lot bi?at in Belisent Four sones swiþe gent, Gveheres & eke Wawain, Gaheriet & Agreuein. Galathin in þis time Com to his moder Blasine & asked, ?if it were soþ, Þat men seyd souþe & norþ: “?if mi nem be king Arthour, Telle me, dame, paramour!” Blasine þo bigan to wepe & seyd: “Sone, so god me kepe, Mi broþer king Arthour is, In on wombe we weren, ywis; Bot he is Vterpendragons stren, Þer fore þi fader him wold slen, & nere þi fader was slawe in fi?t, Nou?t wiþ wrong, bot al wiþ ri?t.” Þer sche him teld anon Arthours bi?ete of Vterpendragon & alle þe destaunce, whi & whar fore Arthours deþ þai hadden yswore, & seyd: “Sone, were þou wiis, Or so þou þe heldest of priis, Þou scholdest bi day & bi ni?t Wiþ queyntise & al þi mi?t Fond, for to maken acord Bitven Arthour & þi lord!” Galathin swore wiþ wordes bold, He nold neuer o?ain hold, & seyd, he wold of him afong Helme & swerd & launce strong & of him be dubbed kni?t & wiþ him be in pays & fi?t. A messanger he sent anon & badde him, swiþe to Wawain gon & sigge him wiþ wordes bonaire, He com to þe newe faire Of Brocklond, to speke him wiþ Mani word of loue & griþ. Þis erand bar þe messanger; Wawain answerd wiþ glad chere, Þat, ?if he hadde liif of manne, He wold speke wiþ him þanne. In time, þat þis sond cam, Gawinet fram hunting nam; Þre grehoundes he ledde on hond & þre raches in on bond. His moder biheld him & wepe sore & seyd: “Sone, now þi nore, Þou lest þi time wiþ vnri?t, Þou hast age to ben kni?t; Þou schust leten þi folye, Þi rage & þi ribaudye; Þenke on þi nem Arthour, Kni?t þat is of mest valour, & fond, to make gode acord Bitven him & Lot, þi lord!” Þer sche told him bifore, Hou Arthour was bi?eten & bore. His brethere seyd, he hadde wrong, For it was al on him ylong, Þat þai here time lorn so, & bot he wald wiþ hem go, Þai wolden fare to king Arthour & him seruen wiþ honour. Þo bispac him child Wawain, Whom Crist ?af boþe mi?t & main: “Swete dame & breþern þre, Wiþ gret wrong ?e blamen me: Seþþen ich euer born was, Nist y neuer are þis cas, Ac, seþþen þus fer comen it is, Y bihote þe king of blis, No schal y neuer armes afong, Bot of king Arthours hond!” His þre breþer on hast Þer biheten anon þat hast. Þo bispac Wawain curteys: “Madame, purvaieþ ous harnais, & we nil neuer blinne, What we may þe acord winne!” “Sone,” sche seyd, “sikerliche, “?e schullen haue neweliche Hors & armes & alle þing, Þat bihoueþ to ?our dubbeing!” Þer after sone, bi godes sond, Galathin went to Brocklond; O?ain him com Wawain, þe fre, Wiþ his gentil breþer þre, & in her to gider coming Þai maden ioie & gret kisseing. Þo seyd Wawain to Galathin: “Certes, gentil nevou min, No hadde it be for loue þine, Ich & al breþer mine Were ywent to our em Arthour, To seruen him & make amour Our fader & him bitven, Þurch help of heuen quen!” “Yherd be Crist,” quaþ Galathin, “Þat is desire & wil min: For þat ich selue þing Ich made after þe sending; To gider, y pray þe, wende we!” “Bleþeliche!” quaþ Wawain, þe fre. Þer þai setten ioifulliche Day, to wende, sikerliche; & ?if þai no hadde to gider ywent, Inglond hadde ben yschent. Mirie is þentre of May, Þe foules make muri play; Maidens singgeþ & makeþ play, Þe time is hot & long þe day; Þe iolif ni?tingale singeþ, In þe grene mede floures springeþ. King Lot & þe leuedi Belisent Hadde puruayd her sone gent Fif hundred on hors wel, In armour of iren & stiel, Erls sones & barouns boþe, Alle in sout of o cloþe; Ac of hem, bot nei?en, kni?t Þer no ware, y ?ou pli?t. He blisced Gawaynet & Gueheres & Gaheriet & Agreuein, þat was so hende, & on godes name bad hem wende. On þis maner dede Blasine, King Nanters leuedi dine: Hir sone Galathin Sche graiþed in atire fin; To hundred feren sche him fond & blisced him wiþ hir hond; Of þis to hundred were .xx. kni?tes, Swiþe noble & gode in fi?tes. Galathin & Gawainet To gider com, þer þai hadde sett, & wenten forþ in her way Toward Londen, for soþe to say; Þai wenden haue king Arthour founde In þe noble toun of Lounde; Þe þridde day in her jurneie Þai were Londen swiþe neie. Þai sei?en hem com swiþe ner Seuen hundred charged somer & seuen hundred cartes al so, & fiue hundred waines after go, Ycharged alle wiþ ale & bred, Wiþ fische & flesche & win red, Robbed of men of þe cuntray, To leden to her ost oway; For þe poudre of þis charging No mi?t men se sonne schining. Þre þousand, seyt our boke, Þat robberie went to loke. Þis robberie þan hadde ydon A king, hi?t Leodebron, & þe king Semgran, Swiþe fel & wicke man, & þe king Mandelec, Þat euer waited scaþe & skec, & þe king Seruagare; Of Yrlond al þai ware; Þis four heþen kinges Went, to loken þis robbeinges, & were so wroþ, þat king Arthour Hadde ywarnist toun & tour, Þat þai þe cuntre aboute Lounde Slowen & brent to þe grounde; Men sei?e þe fer fer away Þennes ouer a iurnay; Man & wiif & children bo No hadde þai no pite to slo; Þe folk schri?ten so hei?e & loude, Þat it schilled in to þe cloude. Wawain sei?e & herd þis fare & asked men, what it ware, & þai him teld sone anon, So ich toforn haue ydon. Wawain asked, where was þe king; Þai seyd, þurch Merlins conseiling He was went to king Leodegon, To help him wer o?ain king Rion. Quaþ Wawayn: “Bi mi leute, We nil suffre now þis pite! Seþþen king Arthour is out of lond, We wil þe painemes wiþstond & saue his lond, we beþ his men, Til þat he com hider o?en!” Þat folk abouten him gan ten & asked, wat folk it mi?t ben; Þai seyden, whos sones þai were & wherefore þai comen þere; Þe folk, þat was of þis lond, Þonked Iesu Cristes sond. Chasteleins sones & vauasours Seþþen wele deden wiþ king Arthours, & fele men of þis lond Þer fellen to þis children hond, Fif hundred of wi?t man. Wawain hete on hast þan Euerich man him arme wel Boþe in yren & in stiel, & suwen him, for her slei?t He wald awreke anon ri?t. Now hadde he a þousand & hundred to, Of wiche four score & no mo Hardi & wele doinde kni?tes, Þat him suwed anon ri?tes In four parties, so y finde, & dede hem o?ain þre þousinde & acontred þat carroy. It was passed þe midday & þo fel fro Wawain Sumdel of his mi?t & main. For of his strengþe þe maner Sumdel ?e may lern & here: Bitven auensong & ni?t He no hadde bot o mannes mi?t, & þat strengþe him last Fort arnemorwe bi þe last; & fram arnemorwe to þe midday He hadde strengþe of kni?tes tvay; Fram midday fort afternone He nadde strengþe bot of one; Fram afternone to auensong So to kni?tes he was strong; Þis was þe manere of Wawain, Of his strengþe & of his main. In þe time of midday On þe paiens he smot, par fay, Wiþ an ex scharp & strong, Þe bite was to fot long; Whom he mi?t take & hitt, Þe heued he clef oþer of kitt; He hem tohewe, ich ?ou swer, So flesche doþ þe flesche heweere; He & his hors fram heued to taile Blodi weren al, saunfayl, Of þe paiems, þat he slou? Wiþ gode ri?t & no wou?. Alder next him was Galathin, Þat him halp wiþ mi?t fin; What Sarrazin so he mett, Wel soriliche he hem grett, Þat, wom euer þat he hitt, Þe heued to þe chinne he slitt, Oþer þe scholder oþer þe heued Fro þe bodi was bireued, Oþer legge oþer fest Oþer what he mi?t take best; Who so euer he atrau?t, Tombel of hors he him tau?t. Wawaines broþer Agreuein Þer him kidde a noble mayn, For .xx. kni?tes al a rawe Þer he brou?t o liue dawe. Þe þridde broþer, Gueheres, Smot him in amid þe pres, On alle half about he smot & mani slou?, god it wot. Þe ?ongest broþer, Gaheriet, No child no mi?t fi?t bet, Þan he dede, verrament; Þer he bisett mani a dent; Þurch armes out euerichon He clef þurch flesche & bon; Fourti Sarrazins & mo Þer he dede to helle go; Oþer men, þat mid him were, Deden nobleliche þere; Þai slou?wen & brou?t to grounde Mani paien in litel stounde. Ac, certes, o?ain Wawain Non no mi?t kiþe his main, For armes non, ywrou?t wiþ hond, O?ain his dent no mi?t stond; Þat he tok, he al torof, So dust in winde & aboute drof; Þer he him contende so manliche, Þat in litel while, sikerliche, Child Wawain & his felawe Þis þre þousand brou?ten of dawe, Bot tventi paiems, þat gun ascape, Fleand oway wiþ gret rape, Of wiche ten com bihinde To on ost of seuen þousinde, Wiþ loude voice & to hem gradde: “Harou, painems, ?e ben to badde: Cartes & somers ous beþ binome & alle our folk is ouercome & yslawe euerich man, Bot we & oþer ten, Þat here bineþe fram ous ?ede, More socour to bring hem midde!” Euerich payem þo was sori & criden a grisely crie: “As armes, for Mahouns sake, Þat þis traitour were ytake!” Þat armes hadde, ron þer to, Ac som no hadde non þo, Ac þai hem hadde laid for hot In þe cartes, god it wot, Wiche þe children hadde sent To Londen, verrament; Alle þe cartes & somers Were sent þider wiþ men of powers. Þis paiens, wiþ outen let, O?ains þis children set; O?ain a þousand come seuen, Þat was no þing delt euen, Ac þe help of our dri?t Wiþ Wawain & his gan ali?t; No herd men neuer so fewe in lond Noblicher so fele wiþstond. Þer aros noble bataile A boþe half, wiþ outen faile, Ac Wawain swiþe noble was, For þer he met king Thoas, A wi?t geaunt, gret & strong, Of fet fourtene he was long, A king he was of Yrlond; Wawain his ax left an hond, On þe helme he him hitt, Þat to þe brest he him slit. Galathin mett king Samgran, An vnsely hoge man; Wiþ his swerd he him hitt, Þat his heued of he kitt; Wawain broþer Agreuain Amid þe pres kidde his main, For a left half & a ri?t He leyd on & slou? doun ri?t. Þer com þe king Gvinbat & ?af Gueheres swiche a flat, Þat he fel adoun to grounde; Ac he stirt vp in a stounde & so smot a Sarrazin, Þat he clef his bacin & eke his heued to þe toþ, & on his hors lepe, for soþ. Gaheriet sei?e Gvinbat, Þat his broþer ?aue swiche a flat, & Gvinbat him com sei?e & gan to flei?e swiþe oway, For þe strokes, he sei?e him ?eue, He no durst abide, so mot y liue, For, þo Gaheriet was ymade kni?t, In euerich place & eueri fi?t He kidde ner as miche main, So dede his broþer Wawain. Gvinbat flei?e out of þe place, Gaheriet on hors his trace Folwed out fram þat ost Wele þe schote of an alblast; So we finden on þe bok, In o valay he him oftok, In wiche valay þe oþer ten, Þat scaped Wawain & our men, Hadden brou?t þousandes ei?t, Of our men to make slei?t. Gaheriet no lete nou?t for þat, Þat he no folwed king Gvinbat, & folwed him, wiþ outen doute, Al on amidward þe route & smot him so on þe helme cler & þer of carf a quarter, & þe scheld þurch ato Wiþ þe scholder & arme al so. King Gvinbat in þat stounde A swon fel adoun to grounde; Gaheriet þo turned his bridel & swiþe wald o?ain ride, Ac þe paiems about him come & wold him han ynome, Ac þer he carf wiþ swerd & smot Mani to þe deþ, god it wot. He nas nou?t tventi winter eld, Ac in armes he was beld; Sum wiþ swerd so he hitt, Þat to þe chin he him slitt; Of mani he smot þe neck ato & wounded & dede michel wo; Non durst him nei?e, verrament, For doute of his hard dent. Þo þai him dede gret vilanie, His hors slou? biforn his ei?e; Gaheriet a fot stode & werd him wiþ hert gode, Boþe he slou? hors & man Him aboute fiue & ten; So sore he hitt, so sore he smot, Non durst him nei?e, god it wot: Þer þai þrewen on him anon Stones & kniues mani on, Swerdes, staues & launces long & wounded him swiþe strong & tviies feld him on þe ston: Allas, help no hadde he non! On him þai schoten attelast & deden of his armes on hast, For to haue anon yreued His bodi fram his gentil heued. In þat time a gentil swain Wel gode scour com to Wawain: “Wawain,” he seyd, “þi broþer y say Riden ?onder to ?on valay, Folwand on heþen king; Me þenkeþ, he makeþ long duelling; Go we þider, for our leudi, Y herd þer gret noise & cri: Y dar legge heued min, Þat þer ben mo Sarrazin, Þat beþ comand hiderward & han þi broþer in hondling hard!” “Allas!” he seyd, “icham yschent, Be mi broþer so yhent: As lef me were, to ben of dawe, As mi broþer were yslawe!” & seyd to Galathin: “Gode nevou, broþer min, ?ond bineþen, icham adred, Þurch his folye he is misled!” Quaþ Galathin: “Lete be þi striif, & wende we þiderward bi liif: While we speki & makeþ tale, He may lachi deþes bale!” Þer þai smiten al about, Þai four dassed out of þe rout. Galathin & eke Wawain, Gveheres & Agreuein, Sum oþer of þe best After þese four þrest; Þo þai sei?en, ich ?ou say, .viii. þousand in o valay, Of wiche her maister king, Was yhoten Gvinbating, Anoþer hi?t Medalan, Boþe wi?t & hoge man; Wawain swiþe among hem smot, His broþer to seche, god it wot; His ex he houe swiþe hei?e, Galathin was him wel nei?e; Þai laiden on hem about & toschiften al þat rout; Sum þe scholder & som þe regge He cleued wiþ swerdes egge, Of sum þe midel ato he girt, Mani he slou? & mani he hirt; Abouten hem swiche slei?st þai made, Þat y no may it nou?t al ful rade. Gveheres & Agrevein Schewed al so her main; Mani þai hitten & smiten þurch, Þat fellen ded in þe furch; No fined þai neuer swiche a slei?t, What þai to Gaheriet com ri?t & pitouseliche him ligge founde Deueling opon þe grounde; Mani on about him were, His armour of þai gun to tere. Þo was Wawain so wroþ, His owhen liif was him loþ; Þer he smot sore, a pli?t, Boþe a left half & a ri?t; On he smot, þat þe dent þrest Þurch helme & heued to þe brest; Anoþer on þe schulder he hitt, Þat to þe ribbes he him slitt; Anoþer he toke aboue þe scheld, Þat his heued flei?e in þe feld: Þus he serued mani a rawe; Al so dede his felawen, So fele þai slowen, hors & man, Þat tellen alle y no can. Þos, þat Gaheriet held þo, Alle hem bifel sorwe & wo; No durst no abide lenge, Ac flowen oway all on renge. Þo Gaheriet sei?e Wawain, He lepe vp wiþ al his main; His armes he tok vp anon & swiftliche dede hem opon & toke a swerd in his hond gode; A fot mani he schadde blode. A destrer þo ladde Agreuein & toke it Gaheriet bi þe rein & seyd: “Worþ her on hastiliche!” & seyd: “þou dedest foliliche, Þo þou folwedest hunting Ani man in þis gret þring!” Vp on þe stede Gaheriet Lepe anon, wiþ outen let; Alle his felawes weren bliþe, Out of þe route dasten swiþe, Anon þai gun hem wiþdrawe, What þai com to her felawe. Þese Sarrazins þo gun vnplie Her baners & after hei?e; To nimen þis children anon, Mahoun þai sworen euerichon; Vnder hem alle so was, y finde, Almest fiften þousinde; Our was litel more þan on, Ac Crist hem halp, wele to don, Our were gode bodis alle, Þe Sarrazins þai gun to talle; A boþe half þai laiden on, So fast so þai mi?ten don. Listneþ now, gret & smale, Hou ?ou seiþ here þis tale! Þe vplondismen, þat hadden ladde Cartes & somers, so Wawain badde, To Londen wel safe þai come; Þe citisains fair in hem nome & asked hem, for heuen king, Whennes com þat noble þing. Alle þai telden, hou Wawain & his feren þurch noble main Hadden met toward Lounde & þre þousand leyd to grounde & þe Sarrazins hadde yschent & to Londen þat catel sent, & seyden to þe constable þo, Þat was yhoten sir Do, Þat Sarrazins seuen þousinde Hadde asailed hem bihinde. Sir Do went to Algate & dede blowe an horn þer ate; Of þat cite þe alderman, Ich wiþ his ward cam; Þo þai were þider ycome, Seuen þousand were in her trome. Þo spac sir Do, þat was kni?t Trewe, hardi & eke wi?t: “Loke,” he seyd, “leue frende: Her bisiden ben childer hende, Þat han þis ich dawe Mani cursed painem slawe, Þat hadden robbed þis cuntray Of al þis ich fair pray; Þis children han hem yschent & þis present hider sent: We were coward & vnhende, Bot we holpen þo children kende; It beþ Galathin & eke Wawain, Gveheres, Gaheriet & Agreuein; Þurch þe grace of Crist Jesu & þis children, y telle ?ou, Bitvene Arthour & þe .xi. king May be pes & acording. As armes,” he seyd, “paramour, & dasse we to her socour!” Wiþ outen abod sone anon Her armes þai deden on; Euerich of þe alderman His baner biforn him nam, & þe constable, sir Do, His baner toke al so. Of þe seuen þousand to þai lete, For alle chaunce Londen to kepe, & wiþ hem toke þousandes fiue, Swiþe gode in fi?t & striue; Her steden swiþe þai bistriden & toward þe children swiþe riden. Lete we now ben her cominge & speke we of þe children fi?ting; Þis children fou?ten, so y finde, O?ain fiftene þousinde & no hadde bot four score kni?tes & fif hundred of squiers wi?t & tventi al so, þat schulden ben Kni?tes, when þai mi?t her time sen, & þre hundred of þe cuntray, Boþe on fot & hors, y say; Þat was a þousand an hundred las; Nas þer namore in þat cas. Ac Gvinbating & Medelan, To vnsely hardi man, Wiþ .viii. þousand in a þrome On our folk dasseand come Wiþ strong cours & gret hete, So þai hem wald nim & þrete. Gvinbating, an hoge spere O?ain Wawain he gan to bere; Wawain it sei?e sone on hast, His scheld þer o?ein gan cast, His scheld perced Gvinbating, Ac his strong hauberk no þing; Þe launce brac atvo, a pli?t, Wawain nou?t stired, ac sat vpri?t, His ax he hef wiþ boþe his hond, To hit Gvinbating, ich vnderstond; On his helme he him smot, Þe ax glod, god it wot; Of þe gode ax þe scharpe egge Fel doun on þe hors rigge & tocarf it euen ato, & to þe grounde, wiþ outen no, Þe kni?t donward gan butten Amidward þe hors gutten, &, no hadde Wawain þer o fot ylawe, He hadde þer þe king yslawe. Þo þe Sarrazin ysei?e þis, Þer com man hundred, ywis, Her lord to ben bitven & Wawain to nimen or slen. Þe Sarrazin her lord vpnome & on hors sett him sone, & sir Wawain þai asailed strong, His hors þai slowen wiþ wrong; Him to nim þai deden strengþe, & non durst him nei?e his ax lengþe, Ac þai him þrewe wiþ swerd & spere, Him to nimen & him to dere. At þat rideing slou? Galathin Swiþe mani Sarrazin; So dede al so Gveheres, Mani heuded in þat pres; Agreuein dede al so, Mani slou? & deden wo; So dede þe child Gaheriet, Noman no mi?t fi?t bet. Miday passed & none cam, Wawain strengþe double gan; Þo he seyd & swore: “Parde, To day no schul ?e nimen me!” Wiþ boþe his honden his ax he hef & fele he slou? in stounde bref; In blod he stode, ichil avowe, Of hors & man in to þe anclowe, Þat he hadde him selue yslawe Wiþ outen slei?t of his felawe. Þo sei?e he, wiþ gret main A paiem smot to Agreuein, Þat he fel on his hors nek, Him to heueden he gan to bek; Wawain wiþ his ax helue Lepe þo fet ten & tvelue & ouer al, þat bitven hem was, To help his broþer in þat cas; Þat ich painem wele he knewe, Þat on his broþer nek hewe; Þe paiem seye, he mi?t nou?t flen, His scheld he kest him bitvene, & Wawain smot on þe scheld, Þat it clef & fel in þe feld; ?ete decended þat ich dent Þurch þe armes, verrament, & þurch out flesche & bon & blode, Þat at þe girdel stede it stode; Þat dede bodi he put adoun & lepe anon in þe arsoun & seyd: “To day ich ?eld ?our rentes Wiþ hard woundes & deþ dentes; Mi strengþe is dubled, bi god aboue, & þat ?e schul ?ete to day proue!” & slou? to grounde al doun ri?t Boþe a left half & a ri?t; So he smot in al þat route, Þat grete hepes him lay about Of mani paiem miscreaunt: Þe Brut þer of is mi waraunt. Agreuein al so wiþ his sword Of Sesox smot þe nek ford; Þat sei?e Gvinbating, þe qued, Þat Sesox, his nevou, was ded, Wreken him he wold fond; A strong launce he tok on hond & smot Agreuein, so god it wold, Þurch þe hauberk fele fold & þurch þern hel vnder þe arm, He hadde nei?e ?ouen him deþes harm, Þat Agreuein & his destrer To grounde he kest wiþ gret power. Gaheriet, Gveheres & Galathin Þo bicome sori afin, For ich of hem wende, certein, Þat dede were Agreuein, & wenten swiþe to þat rideing; Galathin smot first Guinbating Wiþ his sword ful but, Þat on his arsoun dounward he lut. Gveheres him dede more harm, For he smot of his ri?t arm; Forþ com swiþe Gaheriet, He him þou?t to hit bet, For he him tok aboue þe scheld, Þat his heued flei?e in þe feld. Galathin wit fot him stett, Out of his sadel he him pett, & Agreuein tok þat destrer & flei?e þer on so a speruer, & abouten hem þai redden & her noble strengþe kedden; Þo non of hem no wist þere, Whare Wawain was bicomen no where. Al þe ost of Guinbating Flowen to Medelan, þe king, & þo wiþdrou? him Agreuein, What he sei?e child Wawain; Al fiue, to gider þai ?ede, & our folk þo ?ede hem mide. Þo þai loked hem bi side, & sir Do þai sei?e com ride, Whom þai knewe bi þe vplondismen, Þat bifore were went hem fram; Hastiliche þo þai ali?t & on her stedes her sadles di?t. Þis fiue þousand fram Lounde To hem com in a stounde. Þe children were of socour bliþe, Opon her hors þai lopen swiþe Wiþ hem & riden sarreliche Her fon toward, sikerliche; O?ain hem com þe paiems fling For þe deþ of Guinbating; Launces þai broken mani on, Afterward drou? her swerdes anon; For pouder, þat ros hem bitven, Non no mi?t oþer ysen. Þer was noble contenaunce In bataile of remembraunce; Wawain him conteind þan so, Þat men of Londen & sir Do Wonder hadde, hou man on Swiche pruesse mi?t don. So mani paiems, saunfaile, Were yslawe at þat bataile, Þat þe blod ran in þe valaie, So water out of a laie. Þer com þe strong king Medlan & feld Do. þat gentil man. Þe helme hadde him bireued, For to smite of his heued; No man no mi?t him binim, Þat vnsely wiþþerwin, Bot Wawain, þat bi him cam, & he him of his tolling nam; Þat he was gode kni?t, he kidde, Biforn him þe way he ridde, What he com to Medelan, Þat vnsely hoge man; Wawain on þe helme him smot, Þe ax sank depe, god it wot, What he com to þe brest; Þe paiem fel wiþ iuel rest. Þe Sarrazins sei?en þis & gun fle wel swiþe, ywis; Wawain þan & his nevou & his broþer, y telle ?ou, & her feren & sir Do & þe gode men of Londen al so, Driuen hem fiue mile way, & mani of hem, for soþe y say, Þai slou?, þousandes þrettene, Þat nold no more don hem tene, Wiþ outen al þe oþer heþen man, Þat þai slou?wen tofor þan. Þo þis slei?t was ydo, To Lunden al þai comen þo; Men hem o?ain comen of þe toun Wiþ wel fair processioun; Of þe cartes alle þe priis Bifor Wawain þai brou?t, ywis, & sir Do him bisou?t, cert, So he wald, he schuld it part. Wawain seyd to sir Do: “Wo worþ me þan, wo! Ac to hem, þat habben nede mast, Departeþ it now on hast!” Wawain was þe better ay Þer fore ypraised, par ma fay; Þis þing was deled & di?t So hem þou?t best, a pli?t. Þer after þis children of mounde Soiournd wel long in Lounde, Þat no Sarrazin hem mi?t Noiþer deri bi day no ni?t. Sir Do made hem gret solas & alle, þat euer in Londen was. Lete we hem þer soiour & wende o?ain to king Arthour! Marche is hot, miri & long, Foules singen her song; Buriouns springeþ, mede greneþ, Of euerich þing þe hert keneþ. Arthour went to Brekingho, Merlin, Ban, Bohort al so, & her feren fiue & þritti; Was þer no more compainie, Bot in alle fourti & to, Alle chosen, so mot y go, Bi clerk Merlines conseyl, Þe wi?test, þat he wist, saunfail. Forþ þai wenten al in paise, What þai com to Carohaise, A riche cite of al þing; Þer was Leodegan, þe king, Þat was king of al þat lond & hadde Carmelide in his hond, & made swiþe gret pite, For he was bilayn in þat cite Of king Rion & kinges fiftene, Þat al born corounes schene, Þat hadden him & al his man Ouercomen bifor þan, No he no hadde men, þat mi?t Him to awreke, y ?ou pli?t, & conseild him þat ich stounde At kni?tes of þe table rounde & at barouns of þe lond, Hou þai mi?t hem were fro schond. Amid þe strete in þat cite Þe king þer stode wiþ his meine On a palmesonnes aue, Sum conseil of hem to haue. Ri?t þo entred king Arthour & Ban & Bohort & sir Antour & her feren, wiþ outen doute, Al þai comen in on route; Alle it were ?ong man, Bot it were þe king Ban & Bohort & Vlfin þe bel & sir Antour & sir Bretel; Þis were noble kni?tes fiue & alle of midel liue; Þe oþer al were bachelers, Sittand on hei?e destrers. Merlin seyd: “Þe king is ?ounde: Li?teþ al to þe grounde, ?e schullen wende on on ring, ?our hors schul þe gromes bring; & þou, sir Ban, þe king, To Leodegan so ?eue greteing & sey þe wordes him to, Þat we bispeke at Brekenho!” Hou þai went & on wiche maner, Now ?e may al yhere; Of swiche bodis noble & wi?t Tofor men me þink it ri?t, Her names to tellen ?ou in sawe, Hou þai wenten al on rawe. First wenten þre wiþ gret honour: Ban & Bohort & king Arthour; King Arthour ?ede bitven, a pli?t, & king Ban him ledde bi þe hond ri?t; Bohort him ladde nobleliche Bi þe left hond, sikerliche; Alle þe oþer com after þo, Joinand bi hond to & to; Þe ferþ so was Antour, Kayes fader of gret valour; On his hond ?ede sir Vlfin, At euerich nede gode & fin; Þe sext kni?t so was Bretel, Of gret noblay, strong & lel; On his hond ?ede þe steward Kay, Þe seuend kni?t of gret noblay; Þe .viii. Lucan, þe boteler, A gode kni?t of gret power; Erl Does sone, þat loked Lounde, Þe .ix. was, ich vnderstonde; Grifles so was tiþe, Wi?t he was & noble swiþe; Marec so ?ede on his hond, On of þe best of al þat lond; Þe .xii. Drians of þe Forest sauage, A strong kni?t of hei?e parage; Belias, þe lord of Maiden castel, On his hond ?ede fair & wel; The .xiiii. so was Flaundrin, A noble kni?t of gentil lin; On his hond ?ede Lamuas, An hardi kni?t, þe fiftend was; Þe .xvi. was Amores þe broun, A stalworþ kni?t vnder hauberioun; Ancales þe rede ?ede him bi, Þe .xvii. kni?t strong & hardi; Þe .xviii. was Bliobel, A kni?t doand swiþe wel; Þe .xix. was Bleoberiis, Of gret los & michel priis; Canode þe .xx. was, He no flei?e neuer for no cas; Aladanc þe crispe was .xx. & on, Non better bodi no mi?t gon; Þe .xxii. was Islacides, Wi?t & strong in eueri pres; Lampades was .xx. & þre, A noble kni?t, gent & fre; Þe .xxiiii. kni?t was A noble kni?t, yhote Ierias; Cristofer of þe roche norþ Þe .xxv. was, for soþ; Þe .xxvi. was Aigilin, A wi?t kni?t of gentil lin; Þe .xxvii. was Calogreuand, A gentil kui?t of noble hand; Þe .xxviii. was Angusale, Of no man no held he tale; Wi?t Agrauel was .xx. & ni?e, Ful of wi?tschip & curteisie; Þe .xxx. was Cleades, þe fondling, Man sei?e neuer better ?ongling; Þe gode kni?t Gimires of Lambale Þe on & þritti was bi tale; Þe .xxxii. was Kehedin, Fair & wi?t & gentil fin; Þe þre & þritti was Merangis, A gode kni?t of noble priis; Þe .xxxiiii. was Goruain, An hardi kni?t of michel main; Þe .xxxv. was Craddoc, An hardi kni?t in ich floc; Þe .xxxvi. was Claries, He was ful wi?t in eueri pres; Þe .xxxvii. was Blehartis, Bold of dede, of speche wiis; Þe .xxxviii. was Amandauorgulous, A kni?t of dede vertuous; Þe .xxxix. Osoman, cert, His surname was: hardi of hert; Þe .xl. was Galescounde, Þer nas no kni?t of more mounde; Þe .xli. was Bleherris, King Bohortes godsone, ywis; Þe .xlii. Merlin was þar, Bifor Arthour þe ?erd bar; Þis alle ?ede hand in hand, As y ?ou seyd bifornhand. Leodegan & al his ginge Gret wonder had of her cominge; Kni?tes, swaines, leuedis beld Maden crud, hem to biheld; Wonder þai hadden euerichon, For non no knewe her non. O?ain hem ?ede king Leodegan, & him gret þe king Ban; Leodegan seid: “?ou blisse þe rode, ?if ?e beþ ycomen for gode!” Quaþ king Ban: “So Crist me spede, Com we nou?t hider for þi qued No for þi schame, ac for þi gode, So ous help þe gode rode! We beþ souders of fer lond; Men doþ ous to vnderstond, Þat þou to socour haddest nede, Þer fore we com fram our þede, Þat is fer hennes, saunfaile, Þe to help in þi bataile & to serue on swiche maner, So þou schalt now yher: We aske þe on godes name, Noiþer to þine harm no þi schame, Ac þat þou graunt ous now a þing, & þer of no make werning: Þou no schalt aske name our No wo we beþ no non of our, No apose ous of our being, What we þe wil make scheweing; & ?if þe likeþ so our seruise, Telle it ous now in al wise, & bot þou like, we seruen þe, We wille ?ern fram þe te To sum oþer & serue swiþe, Þat of our come wil be bliþe!” Leue toke Leodegan, To asky conseil of his man; Alle his barouns him seyd, ywis, It sembled men of gret priis, Her semblaunt hem bar witnisse; He schuld of hem nim sikernisse & afong her seruise & nou?t hem lete o non wise. O?ain com king Leodegan & þus seyd to Arthour & to Ban: “Bewe seygnours, me þenkeþ schame, Þat ?e me heleþ ?our name, For ich vnderstond wele, þat ?e Ben of more power, þan ich be; Ac ?e semble so wi?t & fre, Þat ?e beþ welcome to me, & ?our seruise ?eld y schal, ?if he me saueþ, þat welt al. Ac arst ?e schul me make siker, Wiþ me held in eueri biker, & ?our names telle ?e me, When ?e seþ, þat time be!” His treuþe þer tok þe king Ban & þer to ?af Leodegan. Þer whiles þe clerk Merlin Hem hadde ypuruaid a riche in & ledde hem þider al faire. Her ost was ycleped Blaire, Leonele hete his wiif, A fair buriays & joliif. Boþe þai wenten o?ain Arthour & him welcomed wiþ gret honour. Arthour & his feren wi?t Soiournde þer seuen ni?t In her in, & wiþ þe king Þai maden oft solausing. Þe king þo sent his messangers Ouer alle to her souders & sent ouer alle in his lond Euerich gentil man his sond, Þat þai comen to him alle To Carohaise into his halle Attelast bi holy þorsday, To help him in his medlay, & who so nold to him come, As traitour he schuld ben ynome, So ich in boke writen finde, & him hing bi þe winde; For so long trewes bitven Rion Weren & þe king Leodegan. Ac listneþ now: swiche traisoun Hem come ar þe assensioun!
