King Harans & his harnoys Went toward þe lond of Leoneis & brent in to þe grounde Al, þat þai biforn hem founde, Man & child þai brent þo & dede hem al michel wo; Sum ascaped wiþ gret paine In to þe cite of Dorkeine & reweliche gun o king Lot For þis lere, god it wot. Lot tok .xx. þousand kni?tes & went him out anon ri?tes; A ferd of .xxx. þousinde He smot on al, so y finde; .v. þousinde in his cominge He slou? wiþ speres meteinge; Egreliche her swerdes drowe & .ix. þousinde þer toslouwe Wiþ so noble swerdes dent, Þat hem astint, verament, & hadde hem alle sone yslawe, ?if Harans, þat þe deuel todrawe, Nadde wiþ .lx. þousand þo Com on our to michel wo, Þat our biclept & wiþ fou?t, & slowen our gentil men & du?t, Þat Lot vnneþe wiþ þre þousinde Scaped at euen, so y finde, In to þe cite of Dorkeine, Sore ywounded wiþ michel peine. Þe king Lot sei?e þis lere, Him selue he gan here tere & bad þe time mesauenture, Þat he cunteked wiþ king Arthour, & his kni?tes, þat leued were, & leuedis & children maden care, For her faders, lordes & frende Were so slawe wiþ helle fende. Harans biseged & dede his peine, Þe cite to winne of Dorkeine. Lot þou?t to saue Belisent, Arthours suster, his quen gent & Wawains moder, saunfail; His kni?tes he asked conseil; Conseil he tok & went bi ni?t Toward Glocedoine ful ri?t, His strong castel, to don in his wiif, For chaunce, þat mi?t be, oþer striif, Wiþ Modred, his sone beld, Þat nas ?ete bot to ?er eld; .v. hundred kni?tes on gode stede Wiþ him he tok for al nede & went toward his castel swiþe; He was þer of seþþen vnbliþe. In þis time child Wawain Wiþ mani feren & eke Ywain, On Arundels wal þai gun leue; A kni?t com arnand wiþ gret reue, Yarmed in armes alle, Þat to Wawain þus gan calle: “Wawain,” he seyd, “Crist þe se & alle þine feren fre! Durst ?e gon wiþ me, siker, Y wold ?ou schewe a selcouþe biker, Whar ?e schul win wining, ?e nold it ?eue for no þing!” “Þan schaltow,” quaþ Wawain, “swere, Þou no schalt ous wiþ tresoun dere!” “Bleþeliche!” he seyd, & swore anon, He no schuld hem qued no traisoun don. Wawain him armed swiþe & tok wiþ him .x. þousand biliue; Þis kni?t sei?e hem com & dassed forþ, & hye him after swiþe norþ; So þai wenten, þai metten a kni?t Arnand wiþ al his mi?t; Wawain nam to þis kni?t hede, Þat he ladde wiþ him Modrede; He rode him to & asked him, whi He ladde his broþer so suiftli. “Wawain,” he seyd, “par ma fay, Al þis ni?t & al þis day Þi lord haþ fou?t o?ain king Taurus, Þre þousand o?ain fiue hundred of ous; Þi lord is wounded, his men be dede, Modred, þi broþer, y tok for drede & wiþ him þus oway drawe, Þat he no ware of hem yslawe!” “Allas,” quaþ Wawain, “allas, allas, Þat ich euer born was! Who schuld euer of me ?elp? Now sterue mi frende wiþ outen help! Frende,” quaþ Wawain, “þou here abide, In on busse þou þe hide, What þou se al þe fulle, Wiche socour don we schulle!” Wawain wiþ his folk forþ drof Hastiliche vnder a grof, Þo he herd a reuly cri, A wiman euer cri merci; He dasched forþ biforn hem alle & sei?e a leuedi þries doun falle Fram Taurus stede to þe grounde, Þat heþen king, þat vnwrast hounde, Þat feloun rage in his wodenesse Pli?t hir vp bi þe tresse, & sche gred: “Seint Marie, Help me, leuedi, Cristes drurie!” & he went vp anon his fest & buffeyt hir vnder þe lest; So oft so sche crid: “Marie!” Sche was buffeit of him þrie; Sche fel doun of his hors rigge & he gan anon his hondes legge On hir tresse & forþ hir drou?; Þe leuedi vp ri?t stode a swou?; He laid on wiþ schourge & bad hir go, & sche no mi?t a fot for wo No for hir cloþes long; Bi hir tresse he gan hir hong, Sche wiþ braid & fel vp ri?t; Taurus ali?t anon ri?t & knett hir to his hors tail Bi her tresse, saunfayl; So he drou? hir him bihinde, Euer “Mari, help!” criinde; What for sorwe & eke for paine, Sche les winde & ek alaine, Hir ei?en turned, hir voice wiþsat, At point of dede was hir stat. Þo seyd to Wawain þat kni?t, Þat hadde him brou?t þider ful ri?t: “Knawestow ou?t þat leuedi, Þat þoleþ al þat vilanie? Wawain,” he seyd, “verrament, Hir name is hote Belisent: Þou ou?test amende hir stat, For þou souke of hir tat!” Wawain was oft wele & wo, Ac neuer wers, þan him was þo; Nei?e aswon he sat vp ri?t, Þo nist he, war bicome þat kni?t, He mi?t long loke after him, He was oway, it was Merlin. Wawain wiþ spors his stede smot, & he forþ stirt, god it wot; He grad aloude to king Taurus; “Abide, þou þef malicious! Biche sone, þou drawest amis, Þou schalt abigge it, ywis!” Þe heþen swain sone doun stett, Þe leuedis tresse sone vnknett. King Taurus was .xiiii. fet long, An vnrede geaunt & a strong; He sei?e to him com Wawain, He toke a launce wiþ gret main & smot þe stede, þat he bistrode; Aiþer to oþer wiþ wretþe rode. Taurus hit Wawain arst, Þat his launce al tobrast; Wawain him hit wiþ main & schof, Þe launce þurch þe scheld drof, Þurch out hauberk & hert polk, & ded him cast among his folk. Wawains breþer on & oþer Smiten euerich liþ fram oþer, & of .v. hundred heþen ichon No leten ascape neuer on. Wawain o?ain went, so seyt þe bok, & his moder in his armes tok & wiped hir mouþe, ei?en & viis; For hir he wepe ful sore, ywis. He kist hir mouþe & hir ei?en, & his breþer þat ysei?en & com to him & gret diol made, No mi?t hem noþing glade, & for loue of hem alle her fere Made wepeing & reuly chere. In al þis diol makeing, Belisent, wiþ outen lesing, Acouerd & vndede her eyin: Þo her sones it yseyn, Þai made joie swiþe gret; Hir ei?en þo sche vndede bet & þonked Iesu, our saueour, Of hir sones gentil socour. Þo teld sche Wawain & his feren, So þat þai it mi?t yheren, Hou Lot wiþ þre hundred kni?t Dede o?ain þre þousand fi?t, & of þe þre þousand he lete oliue, Certes, bot hundredes fiue: “Ac of mi lordes meine, Certes, no scaped oliue nou?t þre; Þo mi lord most chese, Me forgon oþer his liif forlese, Al on he fau?t a mile way Wiþ þo .v. hundred, y say, What he hadde woundes ten & fiue; Vnneþe he ascaped wiþ þe liue, Makand so reuli bere, Þat it was pite for to here. Þe heþen me tok & totoiled, Tobeten, todrawe & defoiled; Now haue ich mi lord ylore & Modred, mi sone, þat wo me is fore!” Aswon þo sche ouerþrewe, Wawain sone hir ablewe & seyd: “Dame, Modred, þi sone, Y schal þe don anon come!” & him ofsent; þo sche him say, Sche akeuered, par ma fay, & was yleyd in liter, Al mast liche an hors bere, & to London toke þe way Wiþ alle Taurus korray, Sex hundred cartes, bi godes ore, Al charged wiþ mete & store. Þo þai to Londen weren ycome, Hendeliche þai were welcome; Do deliuerd þe hei?e palays To sir Wawain, þe curteys; Þer in he dede his leuedi & swore bi þe quen Marie, Schuld her neuer sen his lord, What Arthour & he were acord. Þo he teld al sir Do, Of chaunce þat hem was comen to, Hou he dede Sagremor socour, Þurch an eld vauasour; “& seþþen Ywain, mi cosyn, Þurch leters writen in Latin, Þurch a page al so ri?t, & mi moder þurch a kni?t, & y no couþe non of þo þre Neuer seþþen after yse.” “O Wawain,” quaþ Do anon, “Al þre it was on, Merlin, þe gode felawe; ?ete sum day þou schalt him knawe!” Here of þai hadde wonder & game. Lete we þis rest, in godes name, & telle forþ in gode pays, Hou Merlin doþ his maister Blays In boke writen, saunfaile, Of Inglond þis meruaile & profecies & oþer þing, Þat sum beþ passed & sum coming! Þo went he fram his maister Blais To Arthour, to Carohaise, & teld him & him conseil Of Inglond al þe meruail, Hou Wawain dede & his ferrede & eueriche king in his þede. King Arthour & his ferrade Of þis tidinge were wel glade. Now seiþ our romaunce here, Leodegan sent his messanger To Arthour, Ban & ek Bohort, Þai schuld com to his court, Wiþ him won & soiourne, & seyd, he was sori & murne, Þat he no wist of her beinge, For he vnderstode soþ þing, Þat þai were of power more, Þan he, & hei?er ybore; Þat þai hadde wele yked, Fram deþ when þai him hadde red. He sent hem, to come, bi kni?tes fiue, So þe ?emers of his liue, For al he wald don him, saunfail, In her rede & her conseyl; Wiþ outen bileueing ani more Þai went to him, Merlin bifore. Þo þai comen in to þe halle, Þe king vp stode & his men alle & welcomed hem wiþ bliþeful chere; Þo spac Merlin, so ?e may here: “King, wostow wite our being?” “?a,” quaþ Leodegan, “opon al þing!” “To þis,” he seyd & schewed Arthour, “We sechen a wiif of gret valour!” “A, seynt Marie!” quaþ Leodegan, “& haue ich a douhter, a fair wiman, Fairer not y non, veir, Wise & hende & of mi lond air, & ich ?ou sigge vterliche, Þei in þis warld war non oþer swiche, Þei he no hadde doun no lowe, On him y told hir wele bitowe: So ful y knawe him of worþschipe, Of nortour & of hendeschippe!” He fet his douhter him selue al on — In þis world nas fairer non — & proferd hir to king Arthour, & to ben his air wiþ gret honour; & Arthour hir nome, saunfail, For Merlin him ?af swiche conseil. Now quaþ Merlin to Leodegan: “Wostow now wite, to what man Þou hast y?ouen douhter þin?” “?a, þat were wil & joie min!” Þer he was of Arthour biknawe & of his feren al bi rawe, & seyd, he was her lord bi hirritage, Þai most al don him vmage. Leodegan was þo wel bliþe & to Arthour dede omage swiþe & þe kni?tes of þe rounde table & al þat oþer folk, saun fable. Þer treuþed Arthour Gwenore, his quen, Þe fairest leuedi, þat mi?t ben. King Leodegan lete maken a fest Of alle, þat come, swiþe onest; Ich, þat was of cristen lay, Fond þer fest of gret noblay. Þe fest last seuen ni?t Of al deinte, y sigge, a pli?t, & lenger it hadde ylast, Bot her terme was comen al mast, Þat þai most smite batail O?ain þe Sarrazins, saunfail. Wide & side, ner & fer, Baroun, kni?t & ek souder, Sum bi fe, sum for wining, To Leodegan þe king Were comen to his fi?t & soiournd a fewe ni?t. Mirie is June, þat scheweþ flour; Þe meden ben of swete odour, Lilye & rose of fair colour, Þe riuer cler wiþ outen sour; Boþe kni?tes & vauasour Þis damisels loue paramour. On Mononday in þe pentecost Leodegan & alle his ost Armed hem in aketouns, Hauberkes, plates & hauberiouns, Boþe wiþ bacin & eke palet, & helme on her heued yset; Stones precious & ?immes, Gold & siluer þer were inne; Þai hadde aboue riche queintise Of beten gold of mani a sise; After þat þai her armes bar, Mani was diuers to oþer þar; Mani riche sadel on hast Was on riche destrer cast. Þat ich day paramour Guenore armed king Arthour; At ich armour, þe gest seit þisse, Arthour þe maiden gan kisse. Merlin bad Arthour, þe king, Þenche on þat ich kisseing, When he com in to bataile; “?is,” he seyd, “Merlin, saunfaile!” Þo bad king Leodegan Merlin, ordeine al his man; “Bleþeliche!” he seyd, & ches Arthour & Ban & Bohort of gret vigour & her feren, wiþ outen fable, & kni?tes of þe rounde table, & oþer kni?tes, so y finde, In alle he nam seuen þousinde & made þe first compainie, Him self he wald hem gye. Leodegans nevou, Gogenar, A noble kni?t & wise & war, Merlin toke anoþer ferrede Of seuen þousand forto lede. Þe þridde ledde Elmadas, A ?ong kni?t, þat fin & stalworþ was; He was þe wise leuedis nevou Of þe forest Saunzretour. Þe ferþe led a baroun, hi?t Blias, Þat was lord of Bliodas. Þe fift ledde Andalas, A kni?t of meruailus los he was. Þe .vi. ledde Beliche þe blounde, A kni?t he was of gret mounde. Þe .vii. ledde Yder of Norþlond, Fel & hardi & strong in hond. Þe .viii. ledde Landon, ful of vertu, He was Cleodais nevou. Þe .ix. ledde Gremporemole, Hardi kni?t & wi?t & fre; No kni?t better on stede sat, Ac he hadde a nose as a cat. Ich of þese ladde seuen þousinde. Leodegan so com bihinde Wiþ ten þousinde of þe best. Þo bad hem al Merlin lest: “King,” he said, “nou?t þe amay, For king Rion schal wische þis day, He hadde ?eue þe tounes fiue, He war in his lond wiþ his liue. Fele hundred Sarrazins He haþ wiþ him of biches lins; We schul hem sle & noþing doute, For it is al a curssed route. We han al mast, so y finde, Four score þousinde, & Cristes grace, þat schal ous helpe, To kerue doun ri?t þe heþen welpes. Þenke on ?our childer & wiues & ek on ?our owen liues & of ?our londes, wiþ vnri?t Þai þenke to winne wiþ strengþe & mi?t, ?ou to slen & to exile; Leggeþ on þe traitours vile, Spareþ nou?t, ac sle doun ri?t: ?ou schal help god almi?t! Þai han filled þe michel forest & walled hem bi norþ & west, Þat þer forþ no man no may Comen hem to, par ma fay, & a souþe half walled, certes, Wiþ mani þousand waines & cartes; Ac on þat est half, ich wot, We schul comen opon hem, god it wot, & finde hem slepeand & sle doun ri?t, For þai were al dronken to ni?t!” Þer he ches kni?tes ten & sent biforn her men, For to take & slen & binde Þe spies, þat þai mi?ten finde, Þat so deden & hem bifore Nomen herlotes ten score, & so hem bistirden, þat no tiding Spie no brou?t to þat heþen king. Merlin come bifore wiþ outen þe toun & vnspennid his dragoun, Fer þat kest of þe mouþe, vair, So it li?ted in þe air. Arthour alder next him cam & Ban & Bohort, þat gentil man, & al þat oþer ferred, Ordeind, so ich ere sede. Of armes þat was gret schining, Þe stedes maden gret naying; Þai wenten forþ al so stilly, So þai mi?ten, wiþ outen cri. Þo Merlin com nei?e king Rion, Enchauntement he kest him on, Þat mani of her pauiloun Opon her heuedes fel adoun. Merlin & his feren was, y say, Biforn al þe oþer to mile way; In a Tiwesday in þe daweing He kest þis enchaunteing; Bitven a riuer & a grof He com hem on, þat þai nou?t schrof, & Merlin loude gan to cri: “Help ous now þe quen Marie!” Our folk on þe heþen lusten & vnder hors fet hem frusten & tohewen hem to deþ & ongerten; Þe heþen þeues vp sterten, Four .c. þousand & mani mo To king Rion ascaped þo & armed hem swiftlich vnder his tent; To slen al our, was her entent; Ac our slou? þousandes mani, Ar of hem were armed ani. Ac þo þai hadde keuered armes, Wiþ launces, maces & gisarmes Bi þousandes mani a man Þe heþen smiten our o?an & gun on of þe grest bataile, Þat euer was smiten, saunfaile. Passed was þe day springing, Þe hote sonne was schininge, Þo bigan kni?tes rideing, Trumpes beten, tabours dassing, Þer was fleinge & wiþstonding, Tireing, togging and ouerþroweinge; Of Sarrazins in litel stounde Mani þousand was frust to grounde. Þat sei?e Rion, þat vile hounde, He cleped Salmas, þat kni?t of mounde, Whiche Salmas was his nevou, A stalworþ man & ful of vertu; He tok him an hundred þousand kni?tes & hete him wende anon ri?tes His folk forto socour & awreke his deshonour. Þis Salmas & his wiþ gret vigour Com o?ain king Arthour Wiþ his to & fourti of mounde & wiþ kni?tes of þe table rounde & wiþ oþer, in al, y finde, Þe mountaunce of seuen þousinde. Þo seyd Merlin to king Arthour: “Þenke now of þi newe amour: For loue of þi last kissing Among þis heþen houndes fling!” At þat word king Arthour Smot his stede of gret valour & hit a Sarrazin þurch þe scheld & his hauberk fele feld, Þat þurch þe hert þat ysen cheld Pased, & kest him in þe feld. King Ban bisei?e ri?t so anoþer, & king Bohort, þe þridde, his broþer, Nei?e ichon of her felawe In þe entring brou?t a paien of dawe. Þer was mani stede yfeld, Mani kni?t slawen vnder scheld, Ich kni?t hewe on his per, On schide so doþ þe carpenter. Þer dede so our kni?tes of los, Þat mani paien þer of agros. Arthour was þat day biheld, Hou manliche þat he paiens aqueld, He hem tokarf, he hem tohewe, Mani wiþ ded his dintes knewe. King Jonap, a paien kene, Lengþe he hadde o fet fiftene, He sei?e, hou Arthour ded hem damage; He tok a launce in gret rage & biforn him grop his scheld: Arthour he þou?t his harm to ?eld. Arthour sei?e, wher he cam, A stef launce in hond he nam: He no sembled no more him o?an, Þan doþ a child o?ain a man. Aiþer gan his stede dresse O?ain oþer in þat presse; Jonapes schaft bigan to glide Ri?t bi king Arthour left side Þurch out armes & þurch out schert & in þe side nou?t sore him hert. & Arthour smot him wiþ his launce Þurch out his scheld, wiþ outen balaunce, & þurch out hauberk & aketoun & þurch out þe scholder fer aroum. Jonap was so proude & sterne, No ?af he þer of nou?t a ferne: Wiþ þe brestes so þai metten, Þat to þe grounde boþe þai stetten. Of cristen & heþen þer was toiling, For to help þis to king; Þer was mani swerd ydrawe, Mani kni?t hirt & mani slawe; What wiþ wristling, wat wiþ togging, What wiþ smiteing & wiþ skirminge, On boþe half so þai wrou?ten, Her kinges on hors þai brou?ten. Þo Arthour & his fourti & to & his kni?tes of þe rounde table also So korwen & hewen wiþ mani hond, Þat non armour mi?t hem astond, & so slowen, þat Salmas Flei?e & al, þat wiþ him was. Among þe wele doinde of our men Was on wele fi?tand, hete Nacien, Perciuales cosyn þe fri On his moder half, þat fair leuedi; In þis warld of more noblay Nas non bi Vterpendragones day, No forþ bi þe kinges day Arthour Nas þer non of more vigour; Hauingnes his moder was, Josepes suster, a kni?t of gras, Whom Ebron hadde spouse, A kni?t of dede vertuous, Þat on hur ?at kni?tes seuentene, Hardi & strong, wi?t & kene, In whom seþþen in mani fi?t Al Inglond so was ali?t. Þis was Celidoines cosyn þe rike, Naciens sone of Betike, Whiche Celidoine sei?e first, saunfail, Of þe holi graal þe meruail; ?ete þis Nacien, þe curteis, Was sibbe king Pelles of Listoneis & al his breþer, god it wot, & seþþen hadde Launcelot In his ward al mest a ?er, So þe romaunce seyt elles wher. Þis Naciens, of whom y write, Seþþen bicom ermite & lete kni?tschippe & al þing & bicome prest, messe to sing; Virgine of his bodi he was, Whom seþþen þe holi godes gras Rauist in to þe þridde heuen, Where he herd angels steuen & sei?e fader & sone & holi gost In on substance, in on acost. Þis ?af seþþen þe riche conseil To þe king Arthour, saunfail, Þo he was in gret periil, To lese his londes & ben exil, O?aines þe king Galahos, Þe geauntes sone of gret los, Þat ?af king Arthour bataileinge Wiþ þe power of þritti king. Þis Naciens & Adragenis þe broun Þe heþen kni?tes leyden adoun, Tohewe hem & togert, Y ?ou sigge for soþe, cert. Þe gret strengþe of king Arthour Þes to folweden in alle þe stour So fer, þat he no mi?t se no knowe Neuer on of her felawe. Bifor þes þre Merlin went & bar þe dragoun, þat fer out sent; Þes þre deden michel wo, Hors & man þai coruen ato; Boþe a left half & a ri?t Þai felden kni?tes & slou? doun ri?t & forced hem wiþ mani dent hard, What þai come to king Riones standard, Þat on four castels olifaunce Bar toforn king Riouns; Her feren þo misten hem & smiten after bi .xii. & ten; Wiþ newe grounden fauchoun & sword Mani heued þai smiten ford; Þai schouen wiþ schulder & smiten wiþ arm & deden þe paiens dedliche harm; Ac þai no mi?t keuer to king Arthour Wiþ slei?t no wiþ vigour, Bot Ban & Bohort, so seiþ þe bok, Laiden doun al þat þai tok; Sum in to þe sadel þai smiten, Her swerdes þai dede ful wele biten & so fou?ten & slowen, par ma fay, Þat þai redden & maden way, Maugre þo paiens, þurch fin vigour, What þai com to king Arthour. & þo þai were to gider fiue, Þai binomen mani on her liue; An hundred haþen in litel fitt Þe fiue þurchkoruen & heued ofslit; In ich half was gret fi?ting, Gret slei?t, gret criing, Socouring & wiþstonding; Of kni?tes, barouns, erls & kinge Lay mani heuedeles on þe grounde, On þe gras wiþ dedli wounde, Sum lay wiþ outen fet & armes, Ato ygirt into þe þarmes. Among þis toil sei?e king Rion Our fiue so his men slon; He was seuenten fet long & in þis warld no man so strong; In his ri?t hond & in his left A mace he gan vp lift, Þat no man no schuld bere No vnneþe fram þe grounde stere. In þis time king Fansaron, so mot y liue, Hadde on iuel dent y?eue; Bohort him gan after prike, Curagus, to ben awreke; Fram his feren he folwed him al mast Þe cast of an alblast & hit him þan a dint wel iuel, Þat he fel on his hors a diuel; He wold his nek smiten eft, & þe dint a litel gleft, Þe stedes nek he smot atvo, King Fansaron fel to grounde þo; Bohort him hadde slawe anon, Ac opon hem com king Rion Wiþ þe power of .xviii. kinge, On king Bohort loude gredinge, Þe mace arered in his hond, & said: “Fiz a putain, wiþstonde: Þou schalt abigge, þat þou þer come: Lo here in mine hond þi dome!” Bohort of þe gretnesse hadde meruail & of him was adred, saunfail; Leuer he hadde þer ben yhent, Þan fleand ynomen oþer yschent; He set on him þe crouche verray & him vnder his scheld wray. Rion on þat scheld so smot, Þat it tobrast, god it wot, & king Bohort so smot o?an O þe helme þat hoge man, Þat he sat astoned vp ri?t & nist, wheþer it was dai or ni?t; Þe hors he dast him for bi, & com vp a chaunce, sikerly, Where king Arostus, a geaunt fel, Hadde felled Herui de Riuel, & held him so bi þe code, Þat mouþe & nose him ran a blod, & hadde þer of his heued ysmite, Nadde Adragenis to him stite Wiþ swerd o?ain fourti & mo, King Bohort com rideinde þo & ?aue Aroans wiþ þe swerd a flat, Þat he þrewe of his hors aplat. Herui sei?e legge þe kinges cors, Anon he lepe vp to his hors, & smiten hem amid þe pres, So grehound doþ out of les, & so hewen & laiden on, Þat non mi?t better don. Now is king Leodegan wiþ his folk hard Smiten on kinge Riones standard & doþ gret power, ich ?ou telle, Riones baner forto felle; Ac Rion com & his mace left & slou? a ri?t half & a left; Rion smot to king Bohors & wende, to daschen al his cors, & he failed of him & hit his stede; Þe dent was gret & vnrede, Þe hors chine he dassed ato; Bohort lepe a fot þo & wiþ his swerd, y ?ou pli?t, Wered him anon ri?t. Ac Rion was him about, To nimen & slen wiþ michel rout & dede him tviis knely arawe, & al mast hadde him yslawe. Herui Riuel þis iknewe, King Bohortes harm him gan rewe, Þe stede he smot, þat it quei?te; Of a geaunt a launce he pli?t; To king Rion he gan ride & smot him þurch out þe side; King Rion wiþsat þat dent & smot to Herui, verrament, So þat a quarter of his scheld He bar oway in to þe feld, & eft wald so a deuel wi?t, Ac Herui, þat was vigrous & li?t, On þe scheld him hit a dint hard & cleued it to þe midward, & Rion smot & gan faile & Heruies hors slou?, saunfaile. Þo stode Herui bi Bohort, Boþe in periil of mort, O?aines fele score, y pli?t, & þai hem wered as noble kni?t. Þis sei?e Adregein þe broun; “Now helpe,” he seyd, “seyn Symoun!” He rode to Rion & so him smot, Þat he fel plat, god it wot, Aswon on his hors swere, Mi?t he noiþer se no here; Þe heued he hadde him þer binome, Nadde þe proude king ycome, Rion nevou, Solmas, Þat honged worþ bi þeues las, Bihinde Adrageins com wiþ a spere & to þe grounde gan him bere & bitven þe schulders him hirt; Adragein anon vp stirt On fot & halp his compainoun, So it were a wode lyoun, & so hem wered wiþ steles egge, Þat non no durst on hem hond legge; Ac þai hem þrewe wiþ spere & kniif & oþer armes, to reuen her liif, & wounded hem sore swiþe Þurch out þe armes mani siþe; So þai were ouerriden in a þrawe, Þat nei?e þai hadde ben yslawe, ?if Nacien no had ysein þis, Þat þider smot his stede of pris; Þo, þat in his way he met, Doun ri?t of hors he hem stett; Rion he smot on þe side ri?t & bar him of his hors vp ri?t & rod him on & ouer þries; His hors was slain bitven his þies; Gode & wi?t kni?tes of our Þo stode on fet four, So þai gun fi?t more & lasse, Þat þai made grete tasse; Abouten hem þer þai stode & depe woden in þe blod & made swiche defense & slei?t, Þat y no may telle it ari?t. Ac Rion, þat wiþþerwinne, Dede gret power, hem to nime, & hadde hem nomen, wiþ outen let, No hadde Merlin riden þe bet To king Arthour & to king Ban & seyd: “What do ?e, man? King Bohort & Nacien Beþ ?ond biloke wiþ mani men, & Herui & Agreuein, ?ond þai ben on þe plein; Bot ?e hem soner socour, Þai ben ded al four!” “Allas, allas!” quaþ king Ban, “Lade me þider ri?t onan, For, be mi broþer þer mislad, Worþ y neuer þer after glad!” Merlin smot forþ, þai after dasse On aiþer half, so grehounde of lasse, & her feren after hem come, Þat mani paien ?af her dome & sent hem wiþ scharp sword To þe deuel, her lord. & þo þai comen & sei?en hes, Þai dasched forþ amid þe pres; Euerich hit a paien þo, Þat þai arisen neuer mo; Kni?tes wi?t þai hem kedden & roume to þe four þai redden. Geauntes strong þer weren to, Þe four þat deden michel wo, Minap hete þat on, veires, Þat oþer was hoten Malgleires. King Ban ?af to king Minape On þe helme swiche a clappe, Þat he him cleued to þe toþ; King Arthour smot after, for soþ, So Malgleires hit on þe scheld, Þat his heued flei?e in þe feld. Þes four sei?en her socour & lepen ouer wiþ gret vigour Gret hepes of hors & men, Þat slain lay hem bitven; Hors wel gode chepe þai founde & anon in þe sadel wounde & conteined hem so wi?tliche, cert. So þai nere nou?t yhert. Þo at arst bigan þe bataile. Þat last al day, wiþ outen faile: Ich on oþer so leyd, veir, Þat it dined in to þe air; Also þicke þe aruwe schoten, In sonne bem so doþ þe moten; Gauelokes also þicke flowe So gnattes, ichil avowe; Þer was so michel dust riseing, Þat sen þer nas sonne schineing; Þe trumpeing & þe tabouringe Dede to gider þe kni?tes flinge; Þe kni?tes broken her speren, On þre þai smiten & toteren; Kni?tes & stedes þer laien aboute, Þe heuedes ofsmiten, þe guttes out; Heueden, fet & armes þer Lay strewed eueri wher Vnder stede fet so þicke, In crowes nest so doþe þe sticke; Sum storuen & sum gras gnowe, Þe gode steden her guttes drowe Wiþ blodi sadels in þat pres; Of swiche bataile nas no ses To þe ni?t fram arnemorwe, It was a bataile of gret sorwe. Þer was swiche cark & swiche defoil, Þat al Leodeganes folk made recoil To Denebleise vnder þe wal, Bot Arthour & his folk al, Þat helden hem in þe bataile, Of armes þat dede wonder meruaile. So Leodegan, saunfail, Houed vnder þe cites wal. Sadones seyd, an hardi man, To his em Leodegan: “Listneþ me now, mi lord þe king, & ?e oþer lordinge: What do we here, whi & war fore? ?if we fle, þis lond is lore, & wif & child & al our blisse, Al is forlorn, mid ywis; Better is, to sterue worþschipliche, Þan long to liuen schandfulliche; ?if we be desirite, Our cowardschippe we may it wite; O þing ou?t ous comfort wel: Our newe lord ?ong naturel, Þat so wi?tliche fi?teþ for ous, Helpe we him, for Crist Iesus! ?if he were hunist at þis asaut, He mi?t wite it our defaut, & bot we him help at þis nede, We beþ forswore, so Crist me rede, & ?ete sle þat folk Sarrazine Is our soule medicine!” Ri?t so king Leodegan Gan to crien hem opan; Þo seyd Goionar þe hende: “He naþ non heued, þat nil it defende: Lete be, sir, þi precheing & o?ain þo houndes fling!” Alle þai were at on asent & forþ dassed, verrament; .x. .m. paiens of þos, þai metten, Þurch out hem bar, to grounde he stetten. Þo bigan bataile newe, Ich on oþer wiþ swerd hewe, Wiþ mace & ex & fauchoun Mani kni?t laide oþer adoun. Þer whiles Merlin, so y finde, Dede his out wende, to take þe winde, Gert her steden & ek resten, What þe Sarrazins þresten Our cristen par fors o?an; Þo mounted Arthour, Bohort & Ban Wiþ alle her wi?t compainie, O?ain to bataile þai gun hei?e; Merlin tofore, so seyt þe boke, Wiþ baner feld al, þat he tok. Arthour smot þe king Clarel Bitven þe schulder & þe hatrel, Þat schulder & side & flaunke also Wiþ his swerd he smot ato. He was wroþ, ?e schul here wite, For Merlin hadde him atwite, He hadde iuel ?olden þe kisseinge, Þat Gvenour him ?af at his arminge; Þer fore he tohewe þat route Tofore, biside & al about; Al wondred, þat him sei?e an, & seyd: “He worþ a noble man!” Þo knewe he þurch mani on, Wher þat rod þe king Rion; Þurch corouns & berdes, þat were his armes, He made him way wiþ strengþe of armes, His stede him bar to him anon; Arthour smot to king Rion, A quarter of his helme out hitt & his scheld ato ykitt, & alle his armes, verrament, To þe purpoint of o serpent, Next his schert þat sat þo; Elles he hadde him coruen ato. Rion fel doun wiþ þat dent, So he dede were, verrament. Mani geauntes gret & long About Rion þer were, & strong, Þat on Arthour at ones last & wiþ his hors to grounde him dast; Ac Arthour lepe vp a fot anon & werd him o?ain euerichon. Merlin wist of þis dede & hete al Arthours felawered Wenden swiþe to þis rideing; Tofore dassed Ban, þe king, Al, þat in his way stode, He biheueded hem & lete hem blode, So þat þurch his mi?t gode Þider he com, þer Arthour stode; “Arthour,” he seyd, “þi kinde it nis, To stond o fot, for soþe ywis!” An geaunt he tok anon & cleued him to þe brest bon & brou?t on hors Arthour, ywis, Par fors among his enemis, Þat so þo dede, verrament, Þat non no mi?t stond his dent. Þo Arthour was vp, so y finde, Comen his felawes, .vi. þousinde, & ich of hem on þer hitt, Oþer heued ofsmot or bodi þurch kitt. Þer was defoiled king Rion Vnder stedes fet mani on & drawe & totore vilainliche, Ac he him defended orpedliche; Wiþ gret pine, naþelas, Vp to hors couered he was & smot wiþ mace al about & mani slou? of our rout. Ac an fewe of our best In al þat pres to gider þrest: Arthour & Ban & Bohort, his amis, Naciens & Agraueins & Heruis, Lucans, Griflet, Vlfin & Kay & her feren so fou?ten þat day, Þat in þe cuntre ran heþen blod, So in þe riuer doþ þe flod, & so fou?ten wiþ dintes hard, Þat felled was king Rion standard & þe four olyfaunce yslawe, Baners & castels adoun yþrawe. Þo flei?e Riones folk here & ter, Non durst leue no wher; Ac king Rion þan was so wo, Þat he nist, what he mi?t do; Wiþ his swerd scharp & bri?t .xx. cristen he slou? doun ri?t; Ac his men, þat were him midde, Wiþ strengþe oway wiþ him ride, Ac fram his men he dassed sone Bi a wode oway al one, Makeand, ful sikerly, Swiþe michel diol & cri. Swiche noyse ros in þe bataile, Þat, þei it hadde þondred, saunfaile, No schuld men it yhere, Þe paiens made so rewely bere, & our gred: “Sle, lay on, Kepe þere, kepe here, lete passe non!” Þus þai slou? in litel stounde Mani þousand to þe grounde, & euer þai ben tohewe & smite, So schepe, þat were wiþ wolues ybite. Leodegan & Cleodalis, his steward, Folwed al on Goionard, Riones nevou, þat hadde wiþ him Fele Sarrazins wroþ & grim. Ban & Bohort vertuous, Þai todriuen four kinges orgulous, Þat hete Gloiant & Minados, Calufer & Sinargos; Þe oþer & þo of þe table rounde Bi .v., bi .vi. of gret mounde Were departed her & tar, To folwe þe paiens euer ay whar; Naciens, Adrageins & ek Herui .vi. heþen kinges driuen hardi, Þat hete Mautaile & Fernicans, Bantrines & Kehamans, Forcoars & Troimadac, For to ?euen hem her mat. Alone, certes, king Arthour Drof king Rion wiþ gret vigour; Arthour otok him wiþ drawe sward & seyd: “A?eld þe now, traitour coward!” Arthour on þe helme him smot, Þe dent sanke þurch, god it wot, Þurch þe pelet to þe panne; Ac dedli dent no hadde he nanne. Rion o?ain smot a dent, Ac Arthour him couered, verrament; Of his scheld he carf a corner & of his helme a quarter; Þe dint swarf & flei for bi, Þer fore was non sori; Arthour smot o?ainward Vnder Riones scheld a dint hard & smot Rion þurch armes alle, Þurch þe side nei?e to þe ?alle; King Rion so feld him hert & gan fle ful swiþe, cert; Arthour wald after sue, Ac sex king gun on him hewe, Wiche y nemde tofore ?ou to, Þat Herui drof & his feren al so; Þai grad: “Abide, traitour, on hei?e, Wroþer hole þou Rion sei?e!” Þo lete Arthour Rion scape; Kehenans com wiþ gret rape & ?af king Arthour swiche a las, Þat Arthour al astoned was; Arthour smot þat geant o?an A dint, þat fro main cam, He smot his schulder wiþ arm & scheld, Þat it flei?e in þe feld. Kehenans dede his stede forþ steppe & king Arthour wald bicleppe About his swere wiþ his ri?t arm, Þat þe oþer mi?t don him harm; Ac bitven his hond & elbowe Arthour him ?aue a dint of howe Wiþ his swerd, þat his hond Amidward þe feld wond. Þe stede him bar here & tere, Criand, so wode he were, Ac sone þer after ded doun he þrewe, His soule to þe deuel blewe. Þe oþer dasched on Arthour al fiue, For to reuen him his liue, Ac Arthour king Ferican smot To þe hert, god it wot; Forcoars bi þe side he hitt, Þat ribbes & þi he ofslit. Þo com Naciens, Herui & Adragein, Rideand to Arthour wiþ gret main, Wiþ his to feren king Mautaile Fram Arthour gan swiþe fle; Arthour wiþ his feren þo li?t, Her hors girten & sadles ri?t. Now seiþ here þis romans Of king Bohort & king Bans, So driuen king Minados Wiþ his þre feren of proude los; Þai metten wiþ ten heþen kni?tes, Strong geauntes fel & wi?t, Alle þritten þai smiten þo On our cristen kinges to & perced boþe scheld & armes & dede hem wel gret harmes. Ac Ban hit king Calufer & cleued his heued in to þe swere, After he tok so Sinargos, His heued fram þe bodi was los. Bohort hit king Glorion His ri?t schulder anouen on, Þat al þe schulder & ek þe scheld Wiþ þe ribbes flei?e in þe feld. Sornigrens & Pinnogras, Gaidon & king Margaras Wiþ .vii. heþen, sikerliche, Ban asailed wodeliche. Ac Ban, so noble kni?t & hende, Wi?tliche gan him defende; Pinogras he feld of hors & foiled al his cursed cors; Sornigrens he smot wiþ main Þurch out helme in to þe brain. King Bohort sei?e his broþer fi?t Al on o?ain ten kni?t; Þe stede wiþ þe spors he dust, To þe grounde a paien he frust, Anoþer, þurch helme & bacin Þurch out he clef him to þe chin. Þo þre paiens wiþ wi?t bones On þe helme him smiten at ones, Þat he nei hadde, wiþ outen balaunce, Ylorn hors & contenaunce; Ac he akeuered wiþ hert li?t & smite hem on wiþ main wi?t; Ac in þat ich toilinge Fram Arthour com Rion þe king, Fleand, his swerde drain. & Kay & Griflet & Lucan & Merangis & Craddoc & Geruan & Belchin þe broun & Bleoberiis & Galescounde & Lectargis, Kalogrenant & Kehedins, Folweden & slowen þe Sarrazins Her & ter, so seyt þe boke, & a compeinie oftoke, To hundred paiens, ful of grame, For her ler & for her schame & for king Rion was oway, Her hert was ful of ten & tray; Ich on oþer þer gan smite Wiþ swerdes egge, þat sore gan bite; Þai weren arwe & our hardy & hem todriuen, sikerly, & wenten o?ain to Danbleys, & wiþ outen þe gates, iuel at ayse, Bileueden þer for her king, For to han of him tiding; Þai no hadde of Merlin no conseiling, For he was went, wiþ outen lesing, After king Galat of mi?ti hond, Lord ouer Herdene lond, Wiþ ten þousand, þat was aschape Sarrazins, wiþ gret rape, For to make enchauntement, Hem tofore, verrament. He made alle a valaye Al so it were a brod leye, Þat Galaþ no non of his Þat ni?t no mi?t oway, ywis: Her after sone in þis write, Whi he it dede, ?e schul it wite. Now telleþ þis romaunce, þat king Arthour Com driueand gode scour & bar Marandois in his hond, Worþ al þe swerdes of Inglond, Þat he hadde of Rion wonne; He bad þe king, þat made sonne, For his swete moder loue, He most þat ni?t his swerd proue. Auentours to seke, his stede he smot, King Ban rode after, god it wot, Bohort al so & Nacien, Herui de Riuel & Adragein, & com dasseand al bi cas, Whar Goionar & Salinas Wiþ a kni?t of þe table rounde To .lix. bataile founde. Þese four smot on hem, certes, So þe lyoun doþ on þe hertes; Arthour tau?t on a lessoun of howe & cleued him to þe sadel bowe; Anoþer he biheueded, þe þridde he hit, Vnto þe girdel he him slit; Þe ferþ he tok on þe chine & carf him ato, biliue; Ten, for soþe, in litel þrawe Þer he brou?t o liue dawe Wiþ his swerd Marandoise, Þat carf doun ri?t wiþ outen noise. King Ban smot about al so & cleued a geant atvo; Anoþer he schare of al þe side, Þe þridde he dede of þe heued glide & biheueded þre oþer þer to, & þe seuend he smot ato; & Bohort boþe þi & arm Schare on of & dede him harm; Anoþer he cleued to þe toþ, Þe þridde he biheueded, for soþ; Þe ferþ & fift al so, To helle grounde he dede hem go; Þe gode kni?t Adragein Þurch smot on wiþ gret main; Anoþer he cleued to þe brest & of þe þridde þe heued he daste; Þus he binam þer fiue Al arowe day o liue. Nacien dede ful wel: Wiþ scharp swerd of broun stiel On he cleued doun ri?t & anoþer þer to, a pli?t; Þe þridde to þe brest he cleued & of þe ferþe þe heued ofweued, & þre al so þer to he slou?. Herui al so it made tou?, To þe chine he on slitt & of to þe heued ofkitt. Goiomar & Balinas & þe þridde, þat wiþ hem was, Sei?en her noble socour & leyden on wiþ gret vigour; Ich of hem þo orpedeliche Four slou?, sikerliche; Þo þan leued þer bot ni?e Of al þat iche companie, & þo flowen anon ri?t, Al so swiþe so þai mi?t, Gredeand, it ner non men, Ac deuelen, þat þai fou?ten o?en; Our hem suwed as men kene, Til þai herden michel dene; Boþe on helmes & ysen hatten Þe dintes of swordes flatten. Þo seyd Ban: “We moten heye Al ni?t & wiþ swerd die!” Quaþ king Arthour: “Þat haue y loued, Al what ichaue mi swerd proued!” Quaþ Ban: “?e no haue it nou?t deleid, Þat ?e no haue it wele aseyd!” “Nay, sir,” quaþ Arthour, “þat folk was lite, Þat y no mi?t to wille smite, & to ek þat ?e slou? so fele, Þat half no mi?t y me bistere.” Þo seyden our oþer hem bitvene: “Most he libben & ythen, Bitvene Breteine & Costentinenoble No worþ anoþer kni?t so noble!” Now seyt þe boke, þat sir Antore Wiþ his feren, y nemd bifore, At Danebleise Arthour þai no founde; O?ain þai went in þat stounde Wiþ drawen swerd, to sechen him; An hundred geauntes wroþ & grim Wiþ fauchouns & wiþ swerdes stett, Ich oþer sone mett; Antore was feld among þat floc & Goruain & Gales þe calu & Craddoc & Blioberis & Blichardis, Þat hem defended a fot, ywis, & bi help of her feren seuen O?ain an hundred: þat was vneuen. Arthour com rideinde in þis cas, For sir Antour desmaied was; He smot amidward þe pres, So grehounde doþ out of les; A geaunt sone he tok anne Þurch out helme & heued panne & þurch þe side & þe hert; Of anoþer þe heued he girt; ?ete he tok þe þridde & cleued him to þe midde; In þe swere he toke þe ferþ, Þat þe heued flei?e to þe erþe. Fiue & sex, seuen & ei?te, Orawe he bisei?e so ri?t. Þo gan king Arthour Marmidois, His swerd, to king Ban praise & seyd, it carf so wel, men mi?t delite, Þat witeþ þe geaunce of þis smite. Hem fiue a fot on hors he lift. King Ban aside glift, On a paien wiþ main he girt Þurch out þe heued in to þe hert; Anoþer he schar þe side of; Þe þridde þe heued he al todrof; Þus her & tar he leyd adoun, So it were a wode lyoun. Bohort als a geaunt laiste & þe heued al todaiste; Anoþer to þe chine he karf; Þe þridde he hit, þat he starf; Al abouten he leyd on & slou? to grounde mani on. Adragein wiþ wille fre Arawe biheueded geauntes þre & oþer mo feld to grounde, Þat neuer more ner sounde. Þe gode kni?t also, Herui, Slou? so fele, it was ferly. Nacien, so seyt þe boke, Of a geaunt þat heued he tok; Anoþer to þe chine he lu?ste; Þe schulder of þe þridde he du?ste. Þus þai laiden her & tar & her heuedes fram þe bodi schar. Þe .xii. feren, þat hye þer founde, Non no hadde dedli wounde, Ac þo þai sei?en þis fair socour, Þai laiden on wiþ gret vigour; Ich of hem þre oþer to Of þe paiens biheueded þo; Þer was noble main ysene; Of an hundred, wiþ outen wene, No leued paiens bot fourtene, Þe oþer lay dede opon þe grene, & þe .xiiii. flowen swiþe, So her stedes mi?ten driue; Our sueden wiþ wille fin & metten þe clerk Merlin, Þat hem wiþstode & dede hem li?t, Her stedes girten, her sadles ri?t; So þai dede & blisse made, Ich of oþers helpe was glade. Whiles hye hem graiþeþ, resteþ & ri?teþ, Listneþ, hou Leodegan fi?teþ! Hou Leodegan now vnder an oke Fi?teþ, so seiþ þis boke, Wiþ his steward Cleodalis, Gentil kni?t & trewe, ywis, O?ain seuen & tventi fou?ten hye to, Certes, þat was michel wo. On fot was Cleodalis, So ich ?ou seyd er þis; Leodegan on his hors was, Cleodalis fau?t on þe gras; Wiþ michel sorwe & gret pine Þai werd hem o?ain þo Sarrazine. Colocaulnus, an hoge man, Smot so to Leodegan, Þat he aplat fel of his stede; Boþe mouþe & nose gan blede, For feblenis oþer wounde Strei?t he lay on þe grounde; Þe Sarrazins to him come & þo him wold han ynome, Ac Cleodalis her of nam kepe, He bistride his lord & wepe; Abouten he leyd wiþ his sword & defended his lord, So he smot to his wiþþerwine, Þat non mi?t his lord winne; Þai him þrewe wiþ kniues & stones & ?auen him woundes for þe nones. Vp stirt Leodegan, þe king, Þo passed was his swoninge; His steward mi?t stond vnneþe, For he him forfau?t al to deþe; He sei?e his steward so ful of treuþe, His hert was ful of sorwe & reuþe; He biþou?t him, wiþ wrong His wiif he hadde helden long O?aines ri?t þurch iniquite; A word he seyd of gret pite: “Hay,” he seyd, “Cleodalis, Trewe kni?t wiþ outen feintis, Þurch mi sinne & mi desray Icham comen to mi last day: Haue on me pite, gentil man, & rewe on me, Leodegan! Ich was þi lord, now am y knaue, On me pite & merci haue, For?iue me now þe trespas, Þat y þe haue don, allas! Y pray þe, þat neuer mi misdede Mi soule in to helle lede!” A knowe he sat & seyd: “Merci, Mine owen swerd take, bel ami, Mine heued smite of for mi misdede, Crist me wil þe better rede!” Cleodalis wepe for pite, He sei?e his lord humilite, He lift him vp in his arm & for?af him al þat harm, Þat he him hadde don, & schame, & bad him fi?t, on godes name; So þai deden & fou?ten boþe, Þe paiens þer of weren wroþe; Þo com rideand a geaunt, ywis, & smot to grounde Cleodalis; Þer he lay strei?t along, Leodegan to him sprong & him wered al about Fram al þat ich curssed route; So long he fau?t, he was weri & fel adoun wel dreri. Cleodalis þo vp made a stert, As he nere nou?t yhert, & wiþ main fair & hende His lord, þe king, he gan defende. Þus þai ferd oft, when fel þat on, Þe oþer vp stert þo anon & him defended wiþ alle his mi?t; Þus þai fou?ten til midni?t; Þo were þai wounded so strong, Þat þai no mi?t doure long. To Cleodalis þo seyd Leodegan: “Help now þe self, gentilman, For, to lese & winne al þis lond, Y no may lenger stond!” Often þai made dounfalleing, & when þai mi?t, vpriseing, & halp Cleodalis him, to were & fi?t, Al so wele so he mi?t. In þis time hadde Merlin To Arthour & Ban teld her pine, & þo hadde Leodegan ben ynome, ?if Arthour no had ycome Wiþ his sextene, þat on hem plat, & euerich a paien to deþ flat. Merlin rode out in a stounde & þider brou?t .vii. of þe table rounde, Þat dede wiþ strengþe her swerd baþen In bodi & blod of þe haþen. King Arthour & Bohort & Ban Keuered on hors Leodegan, & Nacien, þat kni?t of pris, On hors keuered Cleodalis, Þat al so wele yfou?ten, cert, So þai ner þat day yhert. Merlin, he tau?t to four geauntes, saun ail, Þat sustend þat bataile; Naciens rod Ancalnus to, Þe side he schar his bodi fro; Arthour cleued king Maulas, & Ban ato girt king Ridras; Bohort biheueded king Dorilan, & ich of þe oþer slou? a paien þan. Þe oþer paiens flowe swiþe, & our went o?ain biliue In to þe cite of Carohaise, Wiþ her feren hem made at aise; Þai maden gret blis & fest & after ?eden hem to rest. He, þat made wiþ his hond Wynd and water, wode and lond, ?eue heom alle good endyng, Þat wolon listne þis talkyng! And y schal telle ?ow byfore, How Merlyn was geten and bore, And of his wisdoms al so And oþre happes mony mo, Sum whyle byfeol in Engelonde, ?e, þat wol þis vndurstonde. In Engelond þer was a kyng, A noble mon in al thyng, In weorre he was war and wy?ht. Kyng Constaunce, for soþe, he hy?t; A dou?hty mon he was of dede And ry?t wys he was of rede. Kyng he was of gret honour And holden prynce and conquerour; For kyng Angys of Denemark And many a Sarsyn stout and stark Weorred on him, wiþ owte faile, And he ouercom heom in batayle And drof heom owt of his lond þat tyde, Þat þey neo durste him nou?t abyde. Þanne hadde þeo kyng sones þreo, Þeo faireste childre þat my?ht beo; Þeo eldest sone, þat schold beo kyng, Was cleped Moyne, wiþ oute lesyng, Þis oþre weore of gret renoun, Boþe Vter and Pendragon: Þus men heore names alle calliþ, Þeo Bruyt witnessiþ heom alle. On þat tyme, we fyndiþ in boke, A gret seknesse þeo kyng toke, Þat out of þis world he most wende, And after his barouns he dude sende. And whan þey weore comen euerilkon, Þe kyng seide to heom anon: “Lordynges,” he saide, “lasse and more, Out of þis world y schal fare: For godis loue and par charite And for þe loue, ?e owen to me, Whan y am ded and lokyn in clay, Helpiþ my childre þat ?e may And takiþ Moyne, myn eldest sone, And makiþ him kyng and ?eueþ him corowne; Holdiþ him ?oure lord for euer mo!” Alle þay graunted, hit scholde beo so. Þan hadde þe kyng a styward feyr, Þat was cleped sir Fortager; His treowthe to þe kyng he ply?t, To helpe his chyldre at his my?t, Bote sone þat traitour was forswore, He brak his treowþe and was forlore. So þat þe kyng of þis world went And faire was buryed, verrayment, At Wynchestre, wiþ oute lesyng, Was mad his burying. Eorles and barouns sone anon Tok heom to gedre euerychon, Wiþ outyn any more dwellyng Heo maden Moyne lord and kyng. Bote þe styward, sir Fortager, Was ful wroþ, as ?e may here, And was þer a?eyn wiþ al his my?t, Boþe by day?es and by ny?ht, For he þou?t him seolue wiþ treson Beo lord and kyng wiþ croun. So sone as Moyne was chose kyng, Into Denemark þe word gon spryng. Kyng Aungys hit herde sayn, Þer of he was boþe glad and fayn; Messangeris þat ilke tyde Wente ouer al his lond wyde After mony Sarsyn stout & stark Of Saxoyne and of Denemark, An hundred þousand and ?et moo On horse and on fote al so Come þydir wiþ oute ensoyne, For to weorre on kyng Moyne. Þeo kyng wolde no lengur byde, Bote dy?t him to schip þat tyde And brou?t in to Engelond afyn Mony a dou?ty Sarsyne. Bote Engelond was clepid þan Mukyl Breotayne of vche man. Þanne þe word wyde sprong, How þe Denys kyng wiþ wrong Gan worche Engelond muche woo; Kyng Moyne herde, þat hit was soo, He went him to sir Fortager And prey?ed him wiþ mouþ and cher And bysou?te him wiþ gret vygour, He scholde beo his gouernour, A?eyn his fomen for to fy?t; And he onswerede anon ry?t And brayd him self seek as traytour strong And saide, wiþ ry?t and nou?t wiþ wrong, Neo wold he neuere come in batayle, For his streynthe bygan to fayle; And al he dude for nyþe and onde: He þou?te to beo kyng of þis londe. Þeo kyng him wolde no more pray, Bote tok his leue and went a way. Messangeris he sent þat tyde Ouer al his lond on ylk a syde To eorl, baroun and to kny?t, To helpe him for to fy?t; And whan þay weore al ycome And heore armes hadde ynome, Þey prikyden forþ, wiþ oute faile, To ?eue þe Denys kyng batayle. Þer was clowen mony a scheld And mony a kny?t feld in þe feld. Al þat þey metten at þat stounde, Mon and hors þey slowe to grounde; So Englysch men, for soþ to say, Weore discomfy?t and fledde away; To Wynchestre þay fledde þo, Syngand allas and weylawo. Bote þe Denys kyng by fore Mukil of his folk hadde ylore; Al so swyþe he sent his sonde Hom a?eyn to his owne londe, To al, þat my?hte wepne beore, Schold come to Englond, him to weore. Alle þe barouns of Engelond Tokyn heom to gedre on honde, What heom weore best to done, To avenge heom of heore fone. And whan þay haddyn spoke of þis, Twolue barons þey sente ywis To sir Fortager þeo bolde, To wite, why þat he neo wolde A?eyn heore fomen for to fonde, To dryue heom out of Engelonde. Þan saide þe barons euerilkon, Þat þey neo scholde neuer spede, Bote ?ef a dou?hty mon of dede Weore chose to beon emperere, And sworen, þat sir Fortagere Was a dou?hty mon of dede, Stout and stark apon a stede, And sweore þer to gedre vchon, Þat oþir kyng no wold þey non.
